headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Susan and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Jabil Second Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn today'
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Susan and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Jabil Second Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn today's call over to Beth Walters, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Ms. Walters, you may begin your conference.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to our Second Quarter of 2012 Earnings Call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Ja
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to our Second Quarter of 2012 Earnings Call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section.
Our second quarter press release and corresponding webcast with slides are also available on our website. In these slides, you will find the financial information that we cover during this call. We ask that you follow our presentation with the slides on the website and beginning with Slide 2, our forward-looking statements.
During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected third quarter of fiscal 2012 net revenue and earning results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2012, on subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and on other securities filings.
Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
And I just realized I must misspoke it, August 31, 2011, not 2012. As we indicated last quarter, we have begun to highlight GAAP operating results. While we currently are still reporting and publishing core results, it is also our intention to move fully to GAAP beginning in fiscal 2013. In addition, we will also be providing guidance on long-term year-over-year outlook. This change to our guidance aligns more closely with how we run the business, making strategic, long-term decisions. We believe providing guidance in this fashion gives investors the most appropriate view into our business.
Today's call will begin with our second quarter results, highlights and comments from Forbes Alexander as well as guidance on our third fiscal quarter of 2012. Tim Main will follow with macroenvironment and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our model and our current outlook. We will then open it up to questions from the call attendees.
I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth. Good evening, everyone. As you're following along, I'd like you to -- if you would turn to Slide 3 of our presentation. Our net revenue for the second quarter is $4.2 billion, an increase of 7.8% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth. Good evening, everyone. As you're following along, I'd like you to -- if you would turn to Slide 3 of our presentation. Our net revenue for the second quarter is $4.2 billion, an increase of 7.8% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $150 million or 3.5% of revenue which compares to $105 million GAAP operating income on revenues of $3.9 billion or 2.7% in the same period in the prior year. Core operating income, excluding the amortization of intangibles and stock-based compensation, increased 4.6% to $176.2 million and represents 4.2% of revenue. This compares to  $168.4 million or 4.3% for the same period in the prior year. GAAP diluted earnings per share for the fiscal quarter was $0.46, an increase of 84% over the prior year. Core diluted earnings per share was $0.58, an increase of 7.4% over the prior year.
If you now turn to Slide 4 for some discussion on our segments. In the second quarter, our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew 33% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.9 billion, representing 44% of total company revenue. Core operating income is 5.9% of revenue. While our Specialized Services group exceeded our expectations from a revenue standpoint, most of the outperformance was driven by the Materials Technology Group. Gains from this group were offset by continued design investments in our health care business and weakness in our Aftermarket Services group where an internal site transition negatively impacted both revenue and segment profitability for the quarter by some 40 to 50 basis points. We expect this transition to be resolved and operating performance within our Aftermarket Services group to return to previous historical levels in the upcoming quarter.
The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment decreased 2% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, representing 29% of total company revenue and core operating income for the segment was 1.7% revenue. Our Enterprise & Infrastructure performance remained below our previous expectations. As a result, continued end market weakness across our telecoms and networking customer base. I shall provide more color towards the end of my prepared remarks on our plans to return this segment to within long term operating range target.
Our High Velocity segment once again operated very efficiently during the quarter. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, down 10% on a year-over-year basis and represents an approximately 20% -- 27%, excuse me, total company revenue in the quarter. Core operating income for this segment was 4% of revenue. The sequential and year-over-year margin outperformance in this segment is primarily associated with a more favorable mix of product. For the second straight quarter, we have 110% customer in each of those 3 segments. While our top 10 customers comprise 61.8% of revenue in the fiscal quarter.
If you now turn to Slide 5, I will review some of our balance sheet metrics. At the end of the quarter, we have cash balances of $707 million. As previously announced, we completed the acquisition of Telmar for $128 million in cash on the 1st of December. And during the course of the quarter, we repurchased approximately 1.7 million shares for an average price of $22.73 per share or approximately $40 million. The impact to EPS for the quarter as a result of these repurchases. On a year-over-year basis, GAAP return on invested capital expanded by 2% to 22% in the first half of fiscal 2012. EBITDA for the same period expanded by $45 million to  $535 million or 6.2%, while cash flows from operations was $5 million. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $77 million or $180 million in the first half of the year.
In the quarter, inventory decreased by 1% to  $2.35 billion, and inventory turns remained at 7. Cash used in operations for the quarter was $109 million as a result of a more nonlinear quarter than we previously anticipated, causing average and period and working capital levels to be elevated. We expect working capital levels to return within recent historical ranges in the coming quarter, and as a result, a return to positive operating cash flows in both our third and fourth fiscal quarters.
I'm also pleased to announce that we have recently amended our bank revolver, adding capacity of $300 million to a total of $1.3 billion and expanding this facility into 2017. This continues to provide us flexibility in our capital structure as we continue to position the company for growth in 2013 and beyond.
You should now turn to Slide 6. We're pleased with our second quarter's results. Core operating margin performance was 4.2%, the midpoint of our guidance while revenues were at the high end of our range. Both core and GAAP EPS also is at the midpoint of our guidance.
If you now turn to Slide 8, 9 and 10. I would like to discuss the outcome the upcoming third quarter's guidance. We expect revenue in the third quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase approximately 2% to the range of $4.2 billion to $4.4 billion. Core operating income is estimated to increase approximately 10% on a year-over-year basis and to be in the range of $185 million to $205 million. Core operating margin in the range of 4.4% to 4.6%.
Our core earnings per share will be in the range of $0.60 to $0.70 per diluted share. And GAAP earnings per share is expected to be in the range of $0.49 to $0.59 per diluted share. This is based upon a diluted share count of 213 million shares. And based upon the current estimate to production, our tax rate on core operating income is expected to be 18%.
Turning to our segments and year-on-year performance, the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment was expected to increase 25% as a result of growth across all areas within this segment. On a sequential basis, the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to grow modestly 2% as we commenced product transitions and additional capital investments in our manufacturing technologies group. The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment is expected to decline 8% on a year-over-year basis.  declines in networking and telecommunications product set, offset by growth in storage. On a sequential basis, the segment is expected to grow 5%, with growth across networking, storage and telecommunications.
And finally, our High Velocity segment, we expect it to decline 14% on a year-over-year basis as a result of continued declines in handset volumes, offset by growth in automotive, point-of-sale printing and our set-top box business.
Capital expenditures in the second half of the fiscal year are expected to be approximately $320 million. The growth of this investment is associated with continued investments in our Materials Technology Group, the group's capacity and capabilities. Total capital expenditures for the full fiscal year are now expected to be approximately $500 million with an excess of 75% of expenditures being invested in our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, positioning this segment for continued growth in 2013 and beyond.
I'd now like to ask you to turn to Slide 11 for a discussion on our Enterprise & Infrastructure segment operating margin performance. This slide shows 2 charts, the top being expected operating margin progression in the upcoming quarter, and the bottom, progression of the return to 4% operating margins in this segment during the first fiscal quarter of 2013 or 9 months from now. We expect the operating margin performance in our third fiscal quarter to improve by some 70 basis points, 25 basis points coming from both the growth in revenues in networking, program wins and product launch and storage and the recovery to growth in the telecommunications sector. The sites we acquired in France and Italy during fiscal '11 and targeted overhead reductions shall contribute 10 basis points each or 0.1% each.
Turning to the chart at the bottom of the slide, we have line of sight to return to growth over the balance of calendar 2012 with revenue growth in storage and networking contributing 1% and 0.35% telecoms revenue growth. Sites in France and Italy are expected to contribute 0.3% to the addition of revenues and cost reduction programs, while targeted overhead reductions across the segment shall yield an additional 0.65%, returning this segment to 4% operating margin performance.
With that, I'd now like to hand the call over to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment and growth by business group, and also for the first time, provide you some perspective on how we're thinking about fiscal year '13.If you pleas
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment and growth by business group, and also for the first time, provide you some perspective on how we're thinking about fiscal year '13.
If you please turn to Slide 13. The Materials & Technology group is really about ingenuity and innovation, and we have invested for growth both in 2010, 2011, 2012, and we expect further growth in 2013. Typically, from the investment of CapEx, there's a lag time of approximately 3 to 6 months as the install the equipment, begin production and manage to higher levels of expected yields in that 4 to 6 month period. Currently managing through significant expansion of our capacity and introducing new product families across a broad range of customers. We're very bullish on another great year of growth and we expect over $3 billion -- roughly $3 billion in fiscal year '12 and hope to grow to approximately $4 billion in FY '13.
Please turn to Slide 14. In our Healthcare & Life Sciences business, Jabil is really a safe pair of hands. We pursue business in essentially 6 modalities: patient bedside, portable on and in-body, surgical and procedural devices, analytical lab equipment, imaging and single-use devices. We're very proud of the customer base that we have and we've spent a lot of time developing new relationships over the last few years. Although there was roughly a flat Europe growth in fiscal year '12, we do expect that rate of growth to accelerate year of as we enter FY '13.
Please turn to Slide 15. This rate of growth is expected to accelerate through the pipeline of growth, particularly to these large portfolios of products that are in our design labs today which will be introduced to production over the course of fiscal '12 and fiscal '13, and we have well over 20 designed with wins in this health care business area, and we're very happy that when those products go into manufacturing, they tend to have typically have a 10-year average product lifecycle. This leads to very sustained growth and gives us a great deal of confidence that our fiscal year '13 and '14 revenue growth should be at the top end of our 20% to 30% revenue guidance for the Diversified Manufacturing Services area.
Turn to Slide 16, please. In Industrial & Clean Tech market, we're really about solving global complexity and enabling innovation. We have business in energy generation, infrastructure, heavy machinery, light goods and a broad range of industrial products. We have some of the leading companies in the world as our customers, spanning activity from smart metering to agriculture, light goods and other types of Clean Tech areas.
Turning to Slide 17, please. We really are developing a global expertise that simplifies complexity. This is a really very high-mix business. Nearly 50% of Jabil's industrial energy manufacturing is in lot sizes of 50 or less. And remember that Jabil's business overall table builds about 70% of its output in large quantities of 100 or less. We need to have very advanced mining tools and to optimize production for these customers and we have very high performance, standardized inter- plant transfer process for business continuity and low transfer costs. We're very excited about continued growth in the Industrial & Clean Tech area.
Please turn to Slide 18. We're enjoying continued success of our core  repair activity in the Aftermarket Services area, and we are seeing additional growth in worldwide parts fulfillment, developing new capabilities that are really taking off now, including diagnostics, distributed screening and customer facing activities. And we expect our growth in Aftermarket Services to continue to be 15% to 20% on an organic basis. Taking our Diversified Manufacturing Services group in total, as we look at fiscal year '13, we see growth in our High Velocity area of approximately 0%; and Enterprise & Infrastructure, 10%; and then you can see Industrial & Clean Tech, Healthcare & Instrumentation and Aftermarket Services, we think these businesses can grow year-over-year on a 15% basis.
Materials Technology Group, as I've mentioned previously, now we expect to have another very robust Europe growth. This will easily support 10% to 15% growth in our fiscal year '13 and we're very excited about our prospects on a longer-term basis. I think we've spent a lot of time focusing on the short term, and we're very pleased with how our business is coming together from a long-term basis and looking forward in FY '13, '14 and '15 and continued growth of 10% to 15%.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Tim, just on to questions just on the capital spending plans around Materials Technology. How much of that comes online as the customer program ramps? And how much overhead do you think you have to carry until you actually get to the full ramp versus the
componenttext: Tim, just on to questions just on the capital spending plans around Materials Technology. How much of that comes online as the customer program ramps? And how much overhead do you think you have to carry until you actually get to the full ramp versus the plant capacity? And then secondly, if you could just go back over the ENI margins, for the quarter, you explain very well what you get from where they are very want by the end of the year. What went wrong during the quarter to keep them at the low levels they were at?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. In terms of Materials Technology Group investments, the slide that we developed and included in our presentation is, yes, Slide 13, is intended to give investors an idea of the lag time between capital investment in the advent of revenue. Revenue wo
componenttext: Okay. In terms of Materials Technology Group investments, the slide that we developed and included in our presentation is, yes, Slide 13, is intended to give investors an idea of the lag time between capital investment in the advent of revenue. Revenue would typically commence approximately 3, 4, 5 months after the investment, and we'd expect to ramp into production through months 4, 5 and 6 and get to more mature yield levels and profitability levels by approximately the 6th months. We're going through our product transition now with new product families that are romping ramping, and we'll be doing that over the course of the spring and the summer and will be making some significant investments. So I would expect the margins in the Materials Technology Group to continue to be in the expected ranges. They'll certainly be better when you reach mature levels of production, a little bit on the lower side during periods of product transitions but still within the targeted range. It's getting to be a very big business, obviously. In half-year it commence we're looking at $1.5 billion for a 6-month period pace in fiscal '12 moving to $2 billion or more on half-year pace in fiscal year '13. So we're very pleased with how that business is coming together and we are adding capacity as we speak. And in the Enterprise & Infrastructure area, there's not a whole heck of a lot to report, Steve, except that revenue was a little bit lower than expected. And we think it's important to really focus on how we get back to 4% from where we are today. And I think we have a good line of sight. My own -- when I look at this business, there has been a very significant slowdown in overall Enterprise & Infrastructure spending from the spring of 2011 when the European debt crisis first emerged, a lot of caution throughout the summer. And as the U.S. had its debt crisis, government spending has been on the decline. That's impacted some of our higher-end government-related types of products. 2,500 spending had collapsed in certain areas of Asia. All of those provided significant headwinds over the last 2 quarters. My experience having been in the business as long as I have is that you have these periods of under investment, a little bit of excess inventory, people work through those and then spending starts to pick up. So provided that the U.S., particularly the U.S. market, continues to not be stable and grow even at a lower rate, I would expect IT Enterprise-related spending to start to pick up midyear and show some more normal levels of at least secular growth rate of 5% to 10% as we exit fiscal '12 and begin our fiscal year '13.

componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of overall revenue line of sight, Brian. We have line of sight for that. There's some great progress in our storage area with new wins there. But ramping this coming quarter given the  great deal of comfort in terms of the rebound, in terms
componenttext: Yes, in terms of overall revenue line of sight, Brian. We have line of sight for that. There's some great progress in our storage area with new wins there. But ramping this coming quarter given the  great deal of comfort in terms of the rebound, in terms of storage and networking. In the short term here and then as we move forward to the balance of the next 3 quarters, continued growth in that area and some rebound with our networking customers there. In terms of overall revenue, what I -- getting the guidance for the full second half of the year, it's somewhere in the region of $210 million, or $250 million, something of that nature. We are seeing a sequential uptick of 5 points this coming 90-day period. And we see any a little bit of tailwind groups to be better than that. But we feel pretty comfortable that the telecommunications business starting to see some pickup there. And I think as we articulated before, we have some wins in the wireless area there where 2 quarters and we're starting see that pick up again, which is good news as we move through the back of calendar '12.

componenttextpreview: This is  filling in for Wamsi. Just wanted to touch on the operating margins for the DMS segment for this quarter. Does the site in EMS that you had an internal transition, could you just elaborate on that? Like why was that needed? Did you move to a low-
componenttext: This is  filling in for Wamsi. Just wanted to touch on the operating margins for the DMS segment for this quarter. Does the site in EMS that you had an internal transition, could you just elaborate on that? Like why was that needed? Did you move to a low-cost location? And is this part of the Telmar acquisition?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's not related to the Telmar acquisition. It's related to the movement of production among sites in Mexico which has been planned for some time. And that transition did not go well. So we think we have that under control now. And I'd point out that EMS
componenttext: It's not related to the Telmar acquisition. It's related to the movement of production among sites in Mexico which has been planned for some time. And that transition did not go well. So we think we have that under control now. And I'd point out that EMS has been -- or Aftermarket Services business has been historically very predictable and very efficient and it's delivered very consistent margins over time. So it's well under control and we are very confident that they'll bounce back to, as Forbes said, historical levels in fiscal Q3. I'd also point out that in terms of the cycle of Diversified Manufacturing Services' operating margins, Q2 for the last 2 years have been the low point. In '10, it was significantly below the targeted range. In '11, it was near the bottom of the range. And in both cases recovered to the 6.5% to 7% areas. So we see no structural issues with that business at all. And as we bring some of these great health care products into the production cycle, we continue to ramp our MTG business, our Industrial & Clean Tech business continues grow in a predictable way and margins in an Aftermarket Services recovers from their product transitions among sites in Mexico, then we have every confidence that Diversified Manufacturing Services will get back to our expectations.

componenttext: We were a little bit puzzled at your math there because we're at 4.2% in Q2. Overall, we're looking for 4.5% in Q3 and that's a 30-basis point improvement to 70-basis point improvement in Enterprise & Infrastructure quarter-on-quarter, and roughly 130 basis points over the next 3 quarters to Q1 of 2013. And Forbes walked through the 4 major elements that that margin improvement expected just in the Enterprise & Infrastructure group. I'd point out to you that even with the underperformance in Enterprise & Infrastructure, the company's doing extremely well from a margin standpoint, fully a couple of hundred basis points against most of our competition. And our EBITDA margin's at 6.2%, lead our industry by a fairly significant margin.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Tim, the number of the EMS companies are talking of, the growth opportunities in the medical and industrial market. I know you laid out some of the winds that you have there but I was hoping to get your view on just kind of the competitive landscape, kind
componenttext: Tim, the number of the EMS companies are talking of, the growth opportunities in the medical and industrial market. I know you laid out some of the winds that you have there but I was hoping to get your view on just kind of the competitive landscape, kind of what you're trying do to differentiate in that space headwinds and your view of kind of the margin profile on an intermediate to longer-term basis.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. We think the margin profile that we've articulated of 6% to 8% is sustainable into the foreseeable future and that's a 3 to 5-year time horizon for Jabil. And we've been operating at that level for the past few years as well so there's some historic
componenttext: Sure. We think the margin profile that we've articulated of 6% to 8% is sustainable into the foreseeable future and that's a 3 to 5-year time horizon for Jabil. And we've been operating at that level for the past few years as well so there's some historical basis for that. I think when you look at Healthcare and Life Sciences, one of the things that we tried to highlight is the many, many design wins, the integration of design, our Materials Technology Group and single-use devices, our optics capability and integrating all of those capabilities into a very broad portfolio of new products that will come out of our product development labs over the next 12 to 18 months and contribute significantly to an acceleration of growth in our Healthcare & Instrumentation area. When I look at Industrial & Clean Tech, although a lot of people talk about it, I don't think that our competitors have the diversity and capability that we do I think we build high-mix electronics, have more low-cost locations than anybody else in the world and we consider Jabil's will be impacted mid-$17 billion range this year or at least about $17 billion of revenue this year and 70% of that output is built in  quantities of 100 less. We are the largest high-mix manufacturing business on the planet, and we think that's a very highly differentiated capability to bring to a market. In a world where virtually all customers are efforting to get to new places, new locations, tap growth in emerging markets, bring new technologies to the products that they have in their portfolio, leverage our product development skills and so helping our customer base manage through that global complexity, architecting -- helping them architect global supply chain networks is a significant differentiator.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up as you talk to customers what's your sense in terms of end demand today versus 3 or 6 months ago and then just kind of inventory adjustments, do you think we're through most of those?
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up as you talk to customers what's your sense in terms of end demand today versus 3 or 6 months ago and then just kind of inventory adjustments, do you think we're through most of those?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- I think it varies, Craig, by business area. In Enterprise infrastructure, my sense is that the mood is turning more towards optimism so I'm -- there is more bias to the upside. I think the overhang of the T-Mobile, AT&T acquisition put a c
componenttext: I think it's -- I think it varies, Craig, by business area. In Enterprise infrastructure, my sense is that the mood is turning more towards optimism so I'm -- there is more bias to the upside. I think the overhang of the T-Mobile, AT&T acquisition put a cap on some needed infrastructure spend in North America. The collapse of 2.5G in China and some of the economic slowdown or worry about economic slowdown in Asia put a kind of a cap on spend there. And of course, we have Europe that's in the midst of a recession. My sense is that most of the inventory issues have been worked through and that we'll see an expansion of spend as some of the uncertainties have cleared down over the last 3 or 4 months. And then as people get progressive -- they've kind of know how the macroeconomic environment does but as long as it stays in the state of even lackluster growth, I think that the bias is more towards the upside. Diversified Manufacturing Services is just going crazy. I mean, we've got great growth there, we've had great weather and we expect to continue to have great growth there. And so our customers are happy with our performance. We're happy with our customers and we feel like we can continue to grow that at a world-class pace. And then High Velocity, that's not an area where we look for a lot of great growth but we have significant customer relationships there. Craig, we're getting pretty good at it. And in High Velocity to -- I don't think we'll continue to earn 4% operating margins in High Velocity. I would expect this Enterprise & Infrastructure margins improve. We might see High Velocity move into the mid-3s because we do need to support customers. It's a very competitive business. But that said, we've really been able to use lean manufacturing and consolidate our operations around the world and get our customers into fewer sites and drive a lot of efficiency that way. So we're very happy with our performance in that area. I don't think the consumer spend has been the great across the board but it's been okay and our customers there are doing pretty well. So I would say we're getting progressively more optimistic over -- than the way things looked 3 or 4 months ago.

componenttext: I just wanted to clarify first, on margins. I'm just trying to understand how we go from the 5.9 to the high 6s over the next 2 to 3 quarters.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that is a fair representation. We would expect particularly in the Aftermarket Services to bounce back to historical levels so that usually gets us into about 6%, 6.4%, 6.5%. And we've got some product transitions going on in Q3 with our inve
componenttext: Yes, I think that is a fair representation. We would expect particularly in the Aftermarket Services to bounce back to historical levels so that usually gets us into about 6%, 6.4%, 6.5%. And we've got some product transitions going on in Q3 with our investments in MTG. But I think a similar ramp through the back half of the year, as what you saw last year, is appropriate. So yes, we feel very comfortable that we can certainly go into that type of recovery back into the targeted ranges.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's certainly been in the cycle of operating margin in that area to rebound from the Q2 period. As Forbes said, there's a very straightforward reason in Aftermarket Services where we have confidence that we'll recover. I think the brighter, the more inte
componenttext: It's certainly been in the cycle of operating margin in that area to rebound from the Q2 period. As Forbes said, there's a very straightforward reason in Aftermarket Services where we have confidence that we'll recover. I think the brighter, the more interesting part of the story is, looking at FY '13 and the growth of the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, if you take what we've shown you on Slide 19 overall, Diversified Manufacturing Services is expected to grow at 22% in FY '13. Overall, that drives about a 12% to 13% growth for the company when you consider Enterprise infrastructure. And if you just look at our margin mix generally speaking, with Diversified Manufacturing Services conservatively in the 6.5% range and then more normalized margins in High Velocity and Enterprise infrastructure should be a great year for us. So I really think that's the more interesting part of the story. As you go quarter-to-quarter, you'll find these areas are relatively arbitrary. We'll have margin a little bit of margin variation as individual aspects of the business do better or worse. We're really happy that revenue is as strong as it was in the quarter, $4.2 billion at the high end of the range, and operating margins are at the midpoint. And EPS and earnings being where they should be in that environment. So it's kind of a bullish set of circumstances for us to be in today, particularly when you consider how we're doing relative to some of the other comparison in the industry that showed contraction in the December period. And we'll see how people do in the March period but I think we're essentially doing a good job of developing the company and showing good earnings in this environment.

componenttext: And then just a final question for me. On your Enterprise & Infrastructure for fiscal '13, I think you put a 10% growth rate expectation, is that just wondering is that all sort of organic or you're expecting some incremental program ramps or market share wins? Just curious of your thought process around versus the 10% growth for fiscal '13.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, there are some new business opportunities, and there always are from time to time in that business but it's a return to secular growth rate as some of the headwinds would be discussed from Europe to mergers between carriers and Asia, along wit
componenttext: Okay. Well, there are some new business opportunities, and there always are from time to time in that business but it's a return to secular growth rate as some of the headwinds would be discussed from Europe to mergers between carriers and Asia, along with inventory corrections. All those things kind of abating, combined with some of the market share wins that we've obtained over the last 12 months and then -- and there are some new business opportunities for us with existing customers. So we're in great shape with our storage customers. We think that telecommunications will start to recover as well as networking. So I'd look at that business over a long-term period of time and say that we will expect that business to grow at kind of a secular growth rate of 6% to 8% which you can look at a number of electronic publications that track growth in enterprise facing and infrastructure industries and that's a kind of a normalized growth rate and we think we can do just a little bit better than that in FY '13.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Hannan with Needham.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: You've provided a lot of great color today. I think everybody appreciates that, certainly ahead of your event coming up in May. The one area I wanted to see if I could focus around was Materials Technology Group. There's been a lot of speculation and news
componenttext: You've provided a lot of great color today. I think everybody appreciates that, certainly ahead of your event coming up in May. The one area I wanted to see if I could focus around was Materials Technology Group. There's been a lot of speculation and news around out there around competitors large and small, I think that you've spoken to this at different points in time. I was looking to see if you could update us on the competition you're seeing within that space, the degree you're seeing even in some cases, perhaps, new entrants or changes in scale or perhaps even pricing at some of the other players.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of competition, it's the usual suspects. I think capture certainly has activity in this area. , Wipro, BYD, these are companies that engage in these types of customers. So the competitors are the same. I think there's -- which is typical for part
componenttext: In terms of competition, it's the usual suspects. I think capture certainly has activity in this area. , Wipro, BYD, these are companies that engage in these types of customers. So the competitors are the same. I think there's -- which is typical for particularly what comes out of Taiwan sometimes, there's an overreaction or dramatization of random news bites that come out. This is a big, exploding marketplace. And I think the thing that people really don't grasp entirely is this is not a mature market yet when we talked about smartphones and higher and higher-end products in the mobility marketplace. Our people believe that we're really in the kind of the beginning years of this expansion and this will be a very big market that will require more than just our MTG group to support. And so we would caution people not to overreact to news bites that come out. Our relationships are very strong. We're expanding capacity with some very strategic customers. We have good line of sight through new product transitions and new product families. So we feel very good about our position. It's a -- can be a really competitive market but our engineering and innovation and ingenuity kind of carries the day for us. And that's what we rely on to be competitive. So we'll continue to keep our technology updated, keep bringing new ingenuity in the marketplace and stay at the forward part of the market developments and not be kind of a fast follower beyond the more commoditized part of the marketplace.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then a follow up, some of your thoughts around that space. Obviously, it's grown very well. A part of that's been on the back of a very large smartphone and tablet OEM. Can you talk about how you'd rank the contributors to that '1
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then a follow up, some of your thoughts around that space. Obviously, it's grown very well. A part of that's been on the back of a very large smartphone and tablet OEM. Can you talk about how you'd rank the contributors to that '13 growth that you're targeting in terms of either further penetration with that largest customer in the space, others perhaps that maybe within the consumer markets. I think that there is an element of some medical customers, a number of programs that'll be coming in as revenues next year, if there is a little bit of insight around how much they could contribute to that 25% growth, that would be helpful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great point. We are very excited about the single-use device market and how we can leverage our skills in MTG into broader participation in the Healthcare & Life Sciences area. I think you'll see increasing contribution from that aspect of o
componenttext: Yes, that's a great point. We are very excited about the single-use device market and how we can leverage our skills in MTG into broader participation in the Healthcare & Life Sciences area. I think you'll see increasing contribution from that aspect of our business in FY '13 and FY '14. That said, I think that the bigger part of the story will continue to be mobility with the existing customer base for the foreseeable future. Just because the numbers are so big, it tends to dwarf the great progress that we're making in areas like health care. But we are very excited about it. It's very meaningful when we look at these plus-20 design wins when we can show them the capabilities that we have to integrate these complex products from optics capability to our MTG capability, along with world-class health care design capability and manufacturing and quality to be a safe pair of hands to bring all of that capably together and really help customers create great new products that they could manifest on their own, or would struggle to manifest on their own, would be a more accurate way to put it. And that's going to be over the next 3 or 5 years, that's going to be an increasingly important part of the business. But Sean, I'd say when we look at FY '13, the bulk of the $1 billion or so of growth that we should see in MTG will be driven primarily through the existing customer base and continued expansion across a broad range of mobility products and accessories.

componenttext: It's -- we would like to have more diversity overall, Amit, and we are adding customers to that portfolio. I'd also like to remind everybody that our larger customers in that business coins with Jabil. So many of the dollars that you see flowing into MTG, a very high percentage of that is matched with coinvestment from customers. So there's a very high level of commitment to the go-forward plan on a long-term basis. So that's really helps us get comfortable with the fidelity of the relationship and the solidity of the go-forward plan.

componenttext: I wouldn't expect the 4% range. We're not providing specific segment margin guidance. it gets a little bit tricky. And I think we'll address long-term targets for that business area later this year on kind of an annual cycle, kind of revisit all of our long-term targets probably on the December call.

componenttext: No, we're really characterizing that as -- we don't for see any specific facility closures or anything of that nature. But really, if you look at the performance that we've put up in terms of the High Velocity business and some of the lean processes, winning our processes, efficiencies there, those will look some of the lessons learned their apply that across our Enterprise & Infrastructure segment. So at this point in time, we're certainly -- and I would not expect any site capacity reductions. But certainly, we will attribute that to much more leaning more to processes and efficiencies running on manufacturing operations.

componenttext: Yes, I think the intangible elements will certainly be attributed directly to the various business units. That's, what, about $16 million, $20 million a year. The stock-based compensation, we're still working through that. That's a little bit trickier in terms of how we allocate that given that that is based on headcount. So we'll continue to work through that and we'll certainly give you more color on that as we move towards the end of the fiscal year here.

componenttext: Yes, maybe 10, 10, 20 basis points for the year. So as we move forward here, we'd certainly expect to see year-over-year expansion in terms of our DMS segment margins. So as we run volumes through there and we start to see some of these design activities come to fruition in terms of revenue flow, the full year's contribution in Telmar for our Aftermarket Services business there and the organic expansion of some opportunities there, we'd certainly expect to see some nice margin, overall margin expansion on both a year-over-year basis and a full fiscal year '13 versus '12 as we move through fiscal '13.

componenttext: Yes, Jim, I think when we look at FY '13 and we look at the growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services relative to the other business areas, DMS should rise to 47%, 48% of the overall business from where it is today. And the basic margin portfolio or margin mix should provide some year-over-year margin expansion for the company overall that will be very attractive.

componenttext: Yes, that's very, very, very good news. And then just is a follow-up, with the CapEx number that's higher. The $0.5 billion  CapEx, should we look at that as kind of a new run rate for the company or kind of a big, big investment here for the company or should we -- im just trying to get a grasp of when CapEx is required given your new business model in DMS and higher profitability?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a great question. We don't know what we're going to spend in FY '13. We're going to have to start expressing this in terms of percent of spend incremental revenue and things like that because the company's getting a heck of a lot bigger and our
componenttext: Well, it's a great question. We don't know what we're going to spend in FY '13. We're going to have to start expressing this in terms of percent of spend incremental revenue and things like that because the company's getting a heck of a lot bigger and our EBITDA margins are increasing. So it's not really -- it's fundamentally quarter-to-quarter, it might look a little odd but fundamentally over the longer term period, it certainly isn't impairing the company's ability quarter-to-quarter to generate cash flows from operations and free cash flow. In fact, we think, in terms of EBITDA yields, we'll still have significant free cash flow over time. The EBITDA margin of 6.2 and we're looking at margin additional margin expansion in FY '13, CapEx could be another $500 million. I don't think it'll be that high but we just don't know at this point. And debt-to-EBITDA margins climbed another 30, 40, 50 basis points, we're going to be generating a lot of cash flow. And even at that level with a $19 billion-plus company, we're going to see pretty good free cash flow, which is still paramount to the company's business plan.

componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. I just wanted to follow up with -- I think last quarter, you talked about a full-year revenue guidance of $17.4 billion for fiscal '12. Are you still comfortable with that? And do you think you could beat that number?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's certainly possible. The midpoint of our guidance of $4.3 billion, that would imply a much bigger Q4 than I'd ask people to model. I think we're very comfortable with the earnings and the operating income so we might have a little bit more of
componenttext: I think it's certainly possible. The midpoint of our guidance of $4.3 billion, that would imply a much bigger Q4 than I'd ask people to model. I think we're very comfortable with the earnings and the operating income so we might have a little bit more of revenue variation, Sherri, than you might -- than what we thought last quarter. But we're still very comfortable with the earnings profile and driving the margins up. So the business mix is actually improving. And so we're less concerned about where exactly where we are revenue could be plus or minus a couple of hundred million dollars and I think would be okay with that as long as the earnings are there in we feel very good about the earnings.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012

componenttext: Okay. Thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call today. componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Susan, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Jabil Second Quarter of Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn today's call over to Beth Walters, Senior Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations. Ms. Walters, you may begin your conference.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to our Second Quarter of 2012 Earnings Call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Ja
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to our Second Quarter of 2012 Earnings Call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander. This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section.
Our second quarter press release and corresponding webcast with slides are also available on our website. In these slides, you will find the financial information that we cover during this call. We ask that you follow our presentation with the slides on the website and beginning with Slide 2, our forward-looking statements.
During this call, we will be making forward-looking statements including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected third quarter of fiscal 2012 net revenue and earning results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. 
An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2012, on subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and our other securities filings.
Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
And I just realized I must misspoke it, August 31, 2011, not 2012. As we indicated last quarter, we have begun to highlight GAAP operating results. While we currently are still reporting and publishing core results, it is also our intention to move fully to GAAP beginning in fiscal 2013. In addition, we will also be providing guidance on long-term year-over-year outlook. 
This change to our guidance aligns more closely with how we run the business, making strategic, long-term decisions. We believe providing guidance in this fashion gives investors the most appropriate view into our business.
Today's call will begin with our second quarter results, highlights and comments from Forbes Alexander, as well as guidance on our third fiscal quarter of 2012. Tim Main will follow with macro-environment and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our model and our current outlook. We will then open it up to questions from call attendees.
I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth. Good evening, everyone. As you're following along, I'd like you to -- if you would turn to Slide 3 of our presentation. Our net revenue for the second quarter was $4.2 billion, an increase of 7.8% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth. Good evening, everyone. As you're following along, I'd like you to -- if you would turn to Slide 3 of our presentation. Our net revenue for the second quarter was $4.2 billion, an increase of 7.8% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $150 million or 3.5% of revenue, which compares to $105 million GAAP operating income on revenues of $3.9 billion or 2.7% in the same period in the prior year. 
Core operating income, excluding the amortization of intangibles and stock-based compensation, increased 4.6% to $176.2 million and represents 4.2% of revenue. This compares to $168.4 million or 4.3% for the same period in the prior year. 
GAAP diluted earnings per share for the fiscal quarter was $0.46, an increase of 84% over the prior year. Core diluted earnings per share was $0.58, an increase of 7.4% over the prior year.
If you now turn to Slide 4 for some discussion on our segments. In the second quarter, our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew 33% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.9 billion, representing 44% of total company revenue. Core operating income is 5.9% of revenue. 
While our Specialized Services group exceeded our expectations from a revenue standpoint, most of the outperformance was driven by Materials Technology group. Gains in this group were offset by continued design investments in our healthcare business and weakness in our Aftermarket Services group, where an internal site transition negatively impacted both revenue and segment profitability for the quarter by some 40 to 50 basis points. We expect this transition to be resolved and operating performance within our Aftermarket Services group to return to previous historical levels in the upcoming quarter.
The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment decreased 2% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, representing 29% of total company revenue and core operating income for the segment was 1.7% revenue. Our Enterprise & Infrastructure performance remained below our previous expectations as a result of continued end market weakness across our telecoms and networking customer base. I shall provide more color towards the end of my prepared remarks on our plans to return this segment to within our long-term operating range targets.
Our High Velocity segment once again operated very efficiently during the quarter. Revenue was approximately $1.2 billion, down 10% on a year-over-year basis and represents an approximately 20% -- 27%, excuse me, total company revenue in the quarter. Core operating income for this segment was 4% of revenue. The sequential and year-over-year margin outperformance in this segment is primarily associated with a more favorable mix of product. 
For the second straight quarter, we have 110% customer in each of those 3 segments. While our top 10 customers comprise 61.8% of revenue in the fiscal quarter.
If you now turn to Slide 5, I will review some of our balance sheet metrics. At the end of the quarter, we've cash balances of $707 million. As previously announced, we completed the acquisition of Telmar for $128 million in cash on the 1st of December. And during the course of the quarter, we repurchased approximately 1.7 million shares with an average price of $22.73 per share or approximately $40 million. There was little impact to EPS for the quarter as a result of these repurchases. On a year-over-year basis, GAAP return on investment capital expanded by 2% to 22% in the first half of fiscal 2012. 
EBITDA for the same period expanded by $45 million to $535 million or 6.2%, while cash flows from operations was $5 million. 
Our capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $77 million or $180 million in the first half of the year.
In the quarter, inventory decreased by 1% to  $2.35 billion, and inventory turns remained at 7. Cash used in operations for the quarter was $109 million as a result of a more nonlinear quarter than we previously anticipated, causing average and period and working capital levels to be elevated. We expect working capital levels to return to within recent historical ranges in the coming quarter, and as a result, a return to positive operating cash flows in both our third and fourth fiscal quarters.
I'm also pleased to announce that we have recently amended our bank revolver, adding capacity of $300 million to a total of $1.3 billion and extending this facility into 2017. This continues to provide us flexibility in our capital structure as we continue to position the company for growth in 2013 and beyond.
You should now turn to Slide 6. We're pleased with our second quarter's results. Core operating margin performance was 4.2%, the midpoint of our guidance, while revenues were at the high end of our range. Both core and GAAP EPS also is at the midpoint of our guidance.
If you now turn to Slide 8, 9 and 10. I would like to discuss the upcoming third quarter's guidance. We expect revenue in the third quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase approximately 2% in the range of $4.2 billion to $4.4 billion. Core operating income is estimated to increase approximately 10% on a year-over-year basis and to be in the range of $185 million to $205 million. Core operating margin in the range of 4.4% to 4.6%.
Our core earnings per share will be in the range of $0.60 to $0.70 per diluted share. And GAAP earnings per share is expected to be in the range of $0.49 to $0.59 per diluted share. 
This is based upon a diluted share count of 213 million shares. And based upon the current estimate to production, our tax rate on core operating income is expected to be 18%.
Turning to our segments and year-on-year performance, the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to increase 25% as a result of growth across all areas within this segment. On a sequential basis, the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to grow modestly at 2% as we commence product transitions and additional capital investments in our Manufacturing Technologies group. The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment is expected to decline 8% on a year-over-year basis, slight declines in networking and telecommunications product set, offset by growth in storage. On a sequential basis, the segment is expected to grow 5%, with growth across networking, storage and telecommunications.
And finally, our High Velocity segment is expected to decline 14% on a year-over-year basis as a result of continued declines in handset volumes, offset by growth in automotive, point-of-sale printing and our set-top box business.
Capital expenditures in the second half of the fiscal year are expected to be approximately $320 million. Majority of this investment is associated with continued investments in our Materials Technology group, group's capacity and capabilities. 
Total capital expenditures for the full fiscal year are now expected to be approximately $500 million with an excess of 75% of these expenditures being invested in our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, positioning this segment for continued growth in 2013 and beyond.
I'd now like to ask you to turn to Slide 11 for a discussion on our Enterprise & Infrastructure segment operating margin performance. This slide shows 2 charts, the top being expected operating margin progression in the upcoming quarter and the bottom, progression of a return to 4% operating margins in this segment during the first fiscal quarter of 2013 or 9 months from now. 
We expect the operating margin performance in our third fiscal quarter to improve by some 70 basis points, 25 basis points coming from both the growth in revenues in networking, program wins and product launch and storage and a recovery to growth in the telecommunications sector. The sites we acquired in France and Italy during fiscal '11 and targeted overhead reductions shall contribute 10 basis points each or 0.1% each.
Turning to the chart at the bottom of the slide. We have line of sight to return to growth over the balance of calendar 2012, with revenue growth in storage and networking contributing 1% and 0.35% telecoms revenue growth. Sites in France and Italy are expected to contribute 0.3% through the addition of revenues and cost reduction programs, while targeted overhead reductions across this segment shall yield an additional 0.65%, returning this segment to 4% operating margin performance.
With that, I'd now like to hand the call over to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment and growth by business group, and also for the first time, provide you some perspective on how we're thinking about fiscal year '13.If you pleas
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment and growth by business group, and also for the first time, provide you some perspective on how we're thinking about fiscal year '13.
If you please turn to Slide 13. Our Materials Technology group is really about ingenuity and innovation, and we have invested for growth both in 2010, 2011, 2012, and we expect further growth in 2013. Typically from the investment of CapEx there's a lag time of approximately 3 to 6 months as we install the equipment, begin production and manage too higher levels of expected yields in that 4 to 6 month period, currently managing through significant expansion of our capacity and introducing new product families across a broad range of customers. We're very bullish on another great year of growth, and we expect over $3 billion -- roughly $3 billion in fiscal year '12 and hope to grow to approximately $4 billion in FY '13.
Please turn to Slide 14. In our Healthcare & Life Sciences business, Jabil is really a safe pair of hands. We pursue business in essentially 6 modalities: patient bedside, portable on- and in-body, surgical or procedural devices, analytical lab equipment, imaging and single-use devices. We're very proud of the customer base that we have and we've spent a lot of time developing new relationships over the last few years. 
Although there was roughly a flat year of growth in fiscal year '12, we do expect that rate of growth to accelerate as we enter FY '13.
Please turn to Slide 15. This rate of growth is expected to accelerate through the pipeline of growth, particularly to this large portfolio of products that are in our design labs today, which will be introduced to production over the course of fiscal '12 and fiscal '13, and we have well over 20 design wins in this healthcare business area. And we're very happy that when those products go into manufacturing, they tend to have -- typically have a 10-year average product life cycle. This leads to very sustained growth and gives us a great deal of confidence that our fiscal year '13 and '14 revenue growth should be at the top end of our 20% to 30% revenue guidance for the Diversified Manufacturing Services area.
Turn to Slide 16, please. In Industrial & Clean Tech market, we're really about solving global complexity and enabling innovation. We have business in energy generation, infrastructure, heavy machinery, light goods and a broad range of industrial products. We have some of the leading companies in the world as our customers, spanning activity from smart metering to agriculture, light goods and other types of Clean Tech areas.
Turning to Slide 17, please. We really are developing a global expertise that simplifies complexity. This is really a very high-mixed business. Nearly 50% of Jabil's industrial energy manufacturing is in lot sizes of 50 or less. And remember that Jabil's business, overall, Jabil builds about 70% of its output in lot quantities of 100 or less.  We need to have very advanced planning tools, techniques to optimize production for these customers and we have very high performance, standardized inter-plant product transfer process for business continuity and low transfer costs. We're very excited about continued growth in the Industrial & Clean Tech area.
Please turn to Slide 18. We're enjoying continued success of our core depot repair activity in the Aftermarket Services area, and we are seeing additional growth in worldwide parts fulfillment, developing new capabilities that are really taking off now, including diagnostics, distributed screening and customer-facing activities. And we expect our growth in Aftermarket Services to continue to be 15% to 20% on an organic basis. 
Taking our Diversified Manufacturing Services group in total as we look at fiscal year '13, I see growth in our High Velocity area of approximately 0%; in Enterprise & Infrastructure, 10%; and then you can see in Industrial & Clean Tech, Healthcare & Instrumentation and Aftermarket Services, we think these businesses can grow year-over-year on a 15% basis.
Materials Technology Group, as I've mentioned previously, now we expect to have another very robust year growth. Now this will easily support 10% to 15% growth in our fiscal year '13, and we're very excited about our prospects on a longer-term basis. 
I think we've spent a lot of time focusing on the short term, and we're very pleased with how our business is coming together from a long-term basis and looking forward in FY '13, '14 and '15 and seeing continued growth of 10% to 15%.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Tim, just on -- 2 questions. First on the capital spending plans around Materials Technology. How much of that comes online as the customer program ramps? And how much overhead do you think you have to carry until you actually get into the full ramp versu
componenttext: Tim, just on -- 2 questions. First on the capital spending plans around Materials Technology. How much of that comes online as the customer program ramps? And how much overhead do you think you have to carry until you actually get into the full ramp versus the plant capacity? And then secondly, if you could just go back over the E&I margins for the quarter, you explain very well what could get you from where they are to where you want them by the end of the year. But what went wrong during the quarter to keep them at the low levels they were at?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. In terms of Materials Technology Group investments, the slide that we developed and included in our presentation is, yes, Slide 13, is intended to give investors an idea of the lag time between capital investment in the advent of revenue. Revenue wo
componenttext: Okay. In terms of Materials Technology Group investments, the slide that we developed and included in our presentation is, yes, Slide 13, is intended to give investors an idea of the lag time between capital investment in the advent of revenue. Revenue would typically commence approximately 3, 4, 5 months after the investment, and we'd expect to ramp into production through months 4, 5 and 6 and get to more mature yield levels and profitability levels by approximately the 6th month. We're going through our product transition now with new product families that are ramping. We'll be doing that over the course of the spring and summer and making some significant investments. So I would expect the margins in the Materials Technology Group to continue to be in the expected ranges. They'll certainly be better when you reach mature levels of production, a little bit on the lower side during periods of product transitions, but still within the targeted range. It's getting to be a very big business obviously. In half year it commenced -- we're looking at $1.5 billion per 6-month period pace in fiscal '12 moving to $2 billion or more half year pace in fiscal year '13. So we're very pleased with how that business is coming together, and we are adding capacity as we speak. In terms of the Enterprise & Infrastructure area, there's not a whole heck of a lot to report, Steve, except that revenue was a little bit lower than expected. And we think it's important to really focus on how we get back to 4% from where we are today. And I think we have a good line of sight. My own -- when I look at this business, there has been a very significant slowdown in overall Enterprise & Infrastructure spending from the spring of 2011 when the European debt crisis first emerged, a lot of caution throughout the summer. And as the U.S. had its debt crisis, government spending has been on the decline. That has impacted some of our higher-end government-related types of products. 2,500 spending had collapsed in certain areas of Asia. All of those provided significant headwinds over the last few quarters. My experience having been in the business as long as I have is that you have these periods of under-investment, a little bit of excess inventory, people work through those, and then spending starts to pick up. So provided that the U.S., particularly the U.S. market, continues to be stable and grow even at a lower rate, I would expect IT Enterprise-related spending to start to pick up midyear and show some more normal levels of at least secular growth rate of 5% to 10% as we exit fiscal '12 and begin our fiscal year '13.

componenttext: Yes. In terms of overall revenue line of sight, Brian, we have line of sight for that. There's some -- been great progress in our storage area with some new wins there that are ramping in this coming quarter, giving me a great deal of comfort in terms of our rebound, in terms of our storage and networking in the short term here. And then as we move forward to the balance of the next 3 quarters, continued growth in that area and some rebound with our networking customers there. In terms of overall revenue, what I -- getting the guidance for the full second half of the year, it's somewhere in the region of $210 million, or $250 million, something of that nature. We are seeing a sequential uptick of 5 points this coming 90-day period. And we don't see any a little bit of tailwind to include -- to be better than that. But we feel pretty comfortable that the telecommunications business, we're starting to see some pickup there. I think as we articulated before, we had some wins in the wireless area there over the 2 quarters, and we're starting see that pick up again, which is good news as we move through the back of calendar '12.

componenttextpreview: This is Ruplu, filling in for Wamsi. I just wanted to touch on the operating margins for the DMS segment for this quarter. Does the site in EMS that you had an internal transition, could you just elaborate on that? Like why was that needed? Did you move t
componenttext: This is Ruplu, filling in for Wamsi. I just wanted to touch on the operating margins for the DMS segment for this quarter. Does the site in EMS that you had an internal transition, could you just elaborate on that? Like why was that needed? Did you move to a low-cost location? And is this part of the Telmar acquisition?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's not related to the Telmar acquisition. It's related to the movement of production among sites in Mexico, which has been planned for some time. And that transition did not go well. So we think we have that under control now. And I'd point out that EMS
componenttext: It's not related to the Telmar acquisition. It's related to the movement of production among sites in Mexico, which has been planned for some time. And that transition did not go well. So we think we have that under control now. And I'd point out that EMS has been -- our Aftermarket Services business has been historically very predictable and very efficient, and it has delivered very consistent margins over time. So it's well under control and we are very confident that they'll bounce back to, as Forbes said, historical levels in fiscal Q3. I'd also point out that in terms of the cycle of Diversified Manufacturing Services operating margins, F Q2 for the last 3 years has been a low point. In '10, it was significantly below the targeted range. In '11, it was near the bottom of the range. And in both cases, recovered to the 6.5% to 7% areas. So we see no structural issues with that business at all. And as we bring some of these great healthcare products into the production cycle, we continue to ramp our MTG business. Our Industrial & Clean Tech business continues grow in a predictable way. If margins in the Aftermarket Services recovers from their product transitions among sites in Mexico, then we have every confidence that Diversified Manufacturing Services will get back to our expectations.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. We think that the margin profile that we've articulated of 6% to 8% is sustainable into the foreseeable future, and that's a 3- to 5-year time horizon for Jabil. We've been operating at that level for the past few years as well, so there's some hist
componenttext: Sure. We think that the margin profile that we've articulated of 6% to 8% is sustainable into the foreseeable future, and that's a 3- to 5-year time horizon for Jabil. We've been operating at that level for the past few years as well, so there's some historical basis for that. I think when we look at Healthcare and Life Sciences, one of the things that we try to highlight is the many, many design wins, the integration of design, our Materials Technology Group and single-use devices, our optics capability and integrating all of those capabilities into a very broad portfolio of new products that will come out of our product development labs over the next 12 to 18 months and contribute significantly to an acceleration of growth in our Healthcare & Instrumentation area. When I look at Industrial & Clean Tech, although a lot of people talk about it, I don't think that our competitors have the diversity and capability that we do. I think we build high-mix electronics in more low-cost locations than anybody else in the world. And when you consider Jabil's -- we'll be in the mid-$17 billion range this year or at least above $17 billion of revenue this year, and 70% of that output is built from lot quantities of 100 or less. We are the largest high-mix manufacturing business on the planet, and we think that's a very highly differentiated capability to bring to a market. In a world where virtually all customers are efforting to get to new places, new locations, tap growth in emerging markets, bring new technologies to the products that they have in their portfolio, leverage our product development skills, so helping our customer base manage through that global complexity of architecting -- helping them architect global supply-chain networks is a significant differentiator.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, as you talk to customers, what's your sense in terms of end demand today versus 3 or 6 months ago? And then just kind of inventory adjustments, do you think we're through most of those?
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, as you talk to customers, what's your sense in terms of end demand today versus 3 or 6 months ago? And then just kind of inventory adjustments, do you think we're through most of those?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- I think it varies, Craig, by business area. In Enterprise & Infrastructure, my sense is that the mood is turning more towards optimism so I'm -- there's more bias to the upside. I think the overhang of the T-Mobile, AT&T acquisition put a
componenttext: I think it's -- I think it varies, Craig, by business area. In Enterprise & Infrastructure, my sense is that the mood is turning more towards optimism so I'm -- there's more bias to the upside. I think the overhang of the T-Mobile, AT&T acquisition put a cap on some needed infrastructure spend in North America. The collapse of 2,500 in China and some of the economic slowdown or worry about economic slowdown in Asia put a kind of a cap on spend there. And of course, we have Europe that's in the midst of a recession. My sense is that most of the inventory issues had been worked through, and that we'll see an expansion of spend as some of the uncertainties have cleared down over the last 3 or 4 months. And then as people get progressive -- they've kind of know how the macroeconomic environment does, but as long as it stays in a state of even lackluster growth, I think that the bias is more towards the upside. Diversified Manufacturing Services is just going crazy. I mean we've got great growth there. We've had great there, and we expect to continue to have great growth there. So our customers are happy with our performance. We're happy with our customers, and we feel like we can continue to grow that at a world-class pace. And High Velocity, that's not an area where we look for a lot of great growth, but we have significant customer relationships there. And you know what, Craig, we're getting pretty good at it. And in High Velocity to -- I don't think we'll continue to earn 4% operating margins in High Velocity. I would expect this Enterprise & Infrastructure margins improve. We might see High Velocity move into the mid-3s because we do need to support customers. It's a very competitive business. But that said, we've really been able to use lean manufacturing and consolidate our operations around the world and get our customers into fewer sites and drive a lot of efficiency that way. So we're very happy with our performance in that area. I don't think the consumer spend has been great across the board, but it's been okay, and our customers there are doing pretty well. So I would say we're getting progressively more optimistic than the way things looked 3 or 4 months ago.
