componenttext: First question on the Enterprise outlook. Can you just talk a little bit more granular on what changed over the last 90 days in the end markets, and if and any of the markets are still growing relative to your previous expectations? And then secondly, just on the expansion that you mentioned in Chengdu, can you talk a little bit more about exactly what's going in there? I think you've ranged it around a couple of businesses, but what's driving it? And if I heard right, I think you said by the end of the calendar year, it's going to be in production and can you just sort of detail that a little bit more?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the Enterprise & Infrastructure, not a dramatic slowdown. In fact, some customers are actually expecting some revenue growth. I think earlier this year, Steven, we were talking -- we were thinking that the second half of calendar 2012 would be a
componenttext: Okay. On the Enterprise & Infrastructure, not a dramatic slowdown. In fact, some customers are actually expecting some revenue growth. I think earlier this year, Steven, we were talking -- we were thinking that the second half of calendar 2012 would be a little bit more robust, Enterprise & Infrastructure customers just because the spending levels have been so low. And typically, what we see is a pattern of underinvestment and in a macroenvironment that has at least some growth, that spending tends to bounce back and there's a catch-up period. I think that's going to happen again. I mean, that the Enterprise & Infrastructure spending is necessary, strategic, important. I think the fiscal constraints that governments are in all around the world has resulted in very low levels of federal spending, government spending in big corporations are risk-averse right now. So I think spend rates have slowed down a little bit. Basically we have a bottom and rebound. And man, are we -- talked with customers in that area. So we will definitely outperform when that bounces back. It's really on the margin a little bit. Again, we expect sequential revenue growth. We have won some new business in the Enterprise infrastructure area. Got a little bit of difficulty transferring them into our facilities but we'll get through that over the course of Q4. Let's say in terms of any helpful color, storage has been a great business area for us and continues to be, that's probably lead in terms of being a robust business area for Jabil. That continues to be a good area for us. But we have great customers in networking and the telecom area as well. You mentioned Chengdu, I need to tread softly there because I can't highlight customers. That would, that would preview individual customers, supply chain strategies and we're not ready to do that and that's consistent with the company's long-term policy. So I'm not doing anything that's out of character for us, but you can bet they're sizable customers with significant requirements and we will -- we intend to be in production by the end of this calendar year. But we can put traditional business in Chengdu. We can put Specialized Services, AMS business, MTG business, all kinds of businesses in Chengdu. It is not being done as a -- I mean, it has the secondary benefit of being a cost edge against close to China and we may be able to use it in future periods. But it's really being put in place to support rising demand with multiple customers.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. It goes without saying that we're in a uncertain macroenvironment. I think we're influenced partly by that environment. There's no reason for us to be a overly aggressive with our confidence about the macroenvironment. That's outside of our control.
componenttext: Yes. It goes without saying that we're in a uncertain macroenvironment. I think we're influenced partly by that environment. There's no reason for us to be a overly aggressive with our confidence about the macroenvironment. That's outside of our control. We did highlight a number of changes occurring simultaneously in High Velocity and Diversified Manufacturing Services and Aftermarket Services. A lot of things for us to focus on this quarter, Wamsi. If we execute very well, I think we'll do well in a -- in a macro environment that doesn't tip over. If the macro situation weakens significantly and we fail to execute that will drive us to the low-end. But I think it's a period where a little bit wider range is very appropriate, given the number of changes in the highly dynamic environment that we're in today.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up. Your comments about consolidation of supply chain that you're in, were you saying that you'll be moving production into sites in Mexico and Hungary or -- do I have that correctly, and then the Chengdu and Wuxi expansions,
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up. Your comments about consolidation of supply chain that you're in, were you saying that you'll be moving production into sites in Mexico and Hungary or -- do I have that correctly, and then the Chengdu and Wuxi expansions, are they also to support this mobility customer?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

componenttext: We did say Mexico, our mobility customer and High Velocity would be consolidating production in Mexico and Hungary for our portion of their requirements. So you did hear that correctly. And given that, the Chengdu and Wuxi operations would be less -- actually, we don't build any requirements in those sites for that particular customer. That particular customer is that mobility customer supported from other sites.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Tim, if you don't mind, I just wanted to follow up on the last question with your margin guidance -- I mean, I think the last time we saw a 4.1% was in the August 2010 quarter, something like $2.86 billion. So just trying to understand maybe you
componenttext: Okay. And Tim, if you don't mind, I just wanted to follow up on the last question with your margin guidance -- I mean, I think the last time we saw a 4.1% was in the August 2010 quarter, something like $2.86 billion. So just trying to understand maybe you can help elaborate how you get to the low-end outside of macro?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm glad you highlighted it, Amitabh, it's been a couple of years [indiscernible] operating margin. That's very helpful. I appreciate that, and I might as well just mention again, that 6.5% EBITDA is the highest level since fourth quarter of 2005. In any
componenttext: I'm glad you highlighted it, Amitabh, it's been a couple of years [indiscernible] operating margin. That's very helpful. I appreciate that, and I might as well just mention again, that 6.5% EBITDA is the highest level since fourth quarter of 2005. In any case, I mean, really is just a matter of -- if revenue is far less than we though and we struggle with some of the operational challenges that we have this quarter, it could drive it to that lower level. Now we have not been at the low-end of our operating margin guidance in my flawed memory for a long time. So even this quarter where our EPS and revenue levels were a little bit mixed, our margins were outstanding. And as Diversified Manufacturing Services continues to grow as a percentage of overall business, I think our margin profile will continue to be attractive but there is a 4.1% of the low-end and it's tough to kind of handicap in the what got some outsized scenarios could happen over the fourth quarter, but if we require quite a few of those downside risk to align together and -- then that's possible. Nothing in particular though. If you think about it, a particular event, there's no particular event that we're trying to handicap in.

componenttext: Forbes, 2 of your competitors talked about taking charges with RIM. Can you discuss kind of what's your thoughts for Jabil if there's any anticipation for some these changes having to take any charges?

componenttext: No, certainly no anticipation there. No.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can follow up with Tim, the technology group, can you talk about the impact of available capacity in that group? Obviously, there's a lot of focus on one big customer but outside of that, are you -- capacity constrained such that as you loo
componenttext: Okay. And if I can follow up with Tim, the technology group, can you talk about the impact of available capacity in that group? Obviously, there's a lot of focus on one big customer but outside of that, are you -- capacity constrained such that as you look to diversify or win new business with new customers, would that impact you in the coming quarters or if you could frame that, that would be helpful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're -- high levels of capacity utilization in our MTG group, we have wide range of sites, subject from Jen Zen to, and Nanjing and Tianjin, Wuxi, Taichung and soon to be Chengdu. So we have a lot of options. The management team in that group tries to ke
componenttext: We're -- high levels of capacity utilization in our MTG group, we have wide range of sites, subject from Jen Zen to, and Nanjing and Tianjin, Wuxi, Taichung and soon to be Chengdu. So we have a lot of options. The management team in that group tries to keep the capacity insulated customer to customer, so the customers don't need to worry about a lack of resource. They're more focused on their particularly production areas. So I think they do a pretty good job of managing that. That's clearly a growth area for us, and we're adding resources and capacity to support a number of customers. But we try and keep them insulated as well as again. Jabil's has got a long history of the business model and keeping operation and operational teams separate so that each customer again rely on us to focus completely on their production requirements to support their needs through the ups and downs of schedule changes. So I don't know if that's helpful or not, but it's probably about the asked extent of what I can say on that, Craig.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. That helps. If I can just -- a quick follow-up on Forbes on the buyback program. If you look at it today versus a year ago when you guys bought back I think $200 million last summer, any constraints on the balance sheet or anything to think about in
componenttext: Sure. That helps. If I can just -- a quick follow-up on Forbes on the buyback program. If you look at it today versus a year ago when you guys bought back I think $200 million last summer, any constraints on the balance sheet or anything to think about in terms of capital allocation in the half back, that would constrain the ability to buy back more stock?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. No constraints from our capital perspective. Our balance sheet is in terrific shape. Should we wish to do anything more of that to EBITDA this quarter as we exit this year, I'll be running about 1.5x. So that's about a level of $1.7 billion. So essent
componenttext: No. No constraints from our capital perspective. Our balance sheet is in terrific shape. Should we wish to do anything more of that to EBITDA this quarter as we exit this year, I'll be running about 1.5x. So that's about a level of $1.7 billion. So essentially what that means is we go somewhere between $1.5 billion and $2 billion of debt capacity available to us. So that in all constraints in that that perspective. We point out we're continuing to invest for growth, I referenced $320 million of capital expenditures, in the back half of the fiscal year. And we have talked about $500 million of CapEx for the next fiscal year. So even at those levels and the cash we're producing, certainly, we have a real comfort of how the balance sheet looks.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

componenttext: So first question. Realizing that RIM really represents most of your handset business there, the consolidation of the factories, that you've already mentioned, is this also going to pertain to all of your handset business or is this just customer-specific?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

componenttext: I -- in my prepared remarks, Sean, I mentioned a single mobility customer in our High Velocity sector intends to consolidate to fuel high capability suppliers. Jabil has been selected as one of those go-forward partners. And at that production, we'll be consolidated regionally in Mexico and Hungary, where we are already in production that customer.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the assembly side, we're just talking that action. Okay. And then separately, on -- I had -- didn't quite get all of the comments around the Telmar. Did I hear that there were some customer issues? We're looking to see if I could get a little
componenttext: Okay. So on the assembly side, we're just talking that action. Okay. And then separately, on -- I had -- didn't quite get all of the comments around the Telmar. Did I hear that there were some customer issues? We're looking to see if I could get a little bit more clarity about what happened to Telmar in the quarter and how to think about that gap of that business as we progressed into Q4 and moving forward.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: What I mentioned is the integration of the Telmar acquisition continues in AMS, and AMS is also -- and there are some expenses associated with that. There's also a number of new service offerings that our multi-country and multilayer that AMS has introduc
componenttext: What I mentioned is the integration of the Telmar acquisition continues in AMS, and AMS is also -- and there are some expenses associated with that. There's also a number of new service offerings that our multi-country and multilayer that AMS has introduced for specific customers, and that's been a drag on earnings in FQ3, and we'll start to improve in FQ4. Telmar, I'd say that we're delighted with the acquisition overall. It's contributing to our service offering for our telecommunications customers in a very deep and meaningful way, and I would expect FY '13 to be much improved in terms of AMS's outlook and their ability to grow on a new vertical on an exciting new area. And so we're really delighted with it. Short-term, we're going to the integration process, and so the accretion levels aren't as what they'll be in a quarter or 2, but we are absolutely delighted with that acquisition and now already seeing synergies develop between Telmar and our AMS Group.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And once you're into that period where you're fully integrated, and you're able to actually see capitalize on the efficiencies are hoping for from either a top line growth perspective or so from a larger standpoint, does that look to be materializing agai
componenttext: And once you're into that period where you're fully integrated, and you're able to actually see capitalize on the efficiencies are hoping for from either a top line growth perspective or so from a larger standpoint, does that look to be materializing again, a few quarters out? The degree you anticipated in doing the deal or is there actually some better, stronger benefits that you may actually capitalize on?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, honestly, I'd say it's been a little bit lighter than I expected in the first couple of quarters of ownership. But that prospectively -- it will exceed its original business plan. So we are starting to realize the revenue synergies that we expected.
componenttext: Yes, honestly, I'd say it's been a little bit lighter than I expected in the first couple of quarters of ownership. But that prospectively -- it will exceed its original business plan. So we are starting to realize the revenue synergies that we expected. So it's been slow, we're getting out of the gate than we expected but we actually think it could be bigger than expected in FY '13.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Matt Sheerin.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Tim, you talked about the growth rates for FY '13 seeking to comments you made out of your Analyst Day and as you look at that pipeline in understanding certainly visibility trend demand is limited here, do you see some of those new business opportunities
componenttext: Tim, you talked about the growth rates for FY '13 seeking to comments you made out of your Analyst Day and as you look at that pipeline in understanding certainly visibility trend demand is limited here, do you see some of those new business opportunities kicking in the November quarter or is that going to be more backend loaded towards the back half of your FY '13?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll look at quarterly guidance in our September call. But I would imagine we've start to see benefits in our first fiscal quarter coming in. That's fair to say and in the year that we guided that we provided a framework for thinking about FY '13, t
componenttext: Yes, we'll look at quarterly guidance in our September call. But I would imagine we've start to see benefits in our first fiscal quarter coming in. That's fair to say and in the year that we guided that we provided a framework for thinking about FY '13, that we should have a good start in the first fiscal quarter. The only caveat to that is we premise that on GDP growth that's positive, and low single-digit. But if the road tips over from a macro standpoint, that's probably not going to be deliverable. But based on what we see today and what we have on our hands, FY '13 should get off to a pretty good start.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the same thing on the margin headwinds that you talked about, some of the new program ramps, customer transitions, Telmar, et cetera, do you also see some margin headwinds on program ramps in the Materials group as you're ramping new produc
componenttext: Okay. And then the same thing on the margin headwinds that you talked about, some of the new program ramps, customer transitions, Telmar, et cetera, do you also see some margin headwinds on program ramps in the Materials group as you're ramping new products for customers in the next quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't provide any margin guidance or color on MTG that's within Specialized Services within DMS and all of the publishers in the DMS area. But any time you're ramping new production, you're less efficient on the front end of that -- on the front end of
componenttext: We don't provide any margin guidance or color on MTG that's within Specialized Services within DMS and all of the publishers in the DMS area. But any time you're ramping new production, you're less efficient on the front end of that -- on the front end of that ramp up and as you get to more mature levels of production, you expect to hit targeted rates of return. And that's pretty much true across-the-board. That's manufacturing as manufacturing, regardless of the activity.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a last question, if I may, just regarding the mobility customer, some of your competitors have walked away from that business and have talked about returns in profitability goals of below their targets. Have you talked to that customer
componenttext: Okay. And then just a last question, if I may, just regarding the mobility customer, some of your competitors have walked away from that business and have talked about returns in profitability goals of below their targets. Have you talked to that customer? Have you -- do you have new contracts in place to ensure that you're going to meet profitability and returns goals?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, that's an existing customer, it's not a customer that I deal with everyday. But our executive staff and key people in our executive staff are in very close contact. And we're kind of appalled at the way people walk away from customers. We believe th
componenttext: Well, that's an existing customer, it's not a customer that I deal with everyday. But our executive staff and key people in our executive staff are in very close contact. And we're kind of appalled at the way people walk away from customers. We believe that if you do business with the customer and they rely on you for a set of services, you should continue to do that through good times and bad. It's a fundamental premise of being in our business. Our customers rely on us to provide, in many cases, 100% of their manufacturing supply chain infrastructure. They cannot deliver products without us. So to the extent that you have a rational economic model and rational risk/reward embedded in contractual agreements and the rest of that kind of staff stuff, there's no reason never to walk away from that customer. And so I think that people talk about stock how they trade trait sometimes more than they think about what makes up a good customer and what doesn't. And we'll see where this goes. But we think that continuing to be a supplier in this regard and enjoy the benefit of that relationship and the investment that's being made in the relationship and the opportunity to continue in production and have adequate returns and a balance between risk and reward is much better for our company and much better for our shareholders then walking away from it.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

Has that changed given some of the of the fluctuations here you're still kind of targeting the type of cost reduction within E&I, as we look over the next say, 2 to 3 quarters?

componenttext: Yes, I think certainly, we've commented in the prepared remarks that we're not seeing the revenue growth that perhaps we saw 90 days ago. So -- but we still believe that the focus and end target is within our range over the next couple of 3 quarters here. So if we don't see those benefits from a revenue list, we'll appropriately shift the cost structure. So certainly, it will be around about those levels, perhaps a little bit higher depending upon the revenue stream you see as we move through the next 90 or 120 days or so.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I mean, just looking kind of the 3 business units moving to the fourth quarter, is there anything happening in terms of the individual EBIT margins that would push them down beyond kind of volumes? Because it seems as if just the low-end of the
componenttext: Okay, and I mean, just looking kind of the 3 business units moving to the fourth quarter, is there anything happening in terms of the individual EBIT margins that would push them down beyond kind of volumes? Because it seems as if just the low-end of the guidance maybe to paraphrase it earlier, just kind of a worst-case scenario that you'll be baking and otherwise, it will be kind of normal incremental margins on any type of volume dynamic.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's nothing specific that we are baking in. I think the standby -- in Tim's comments, to an earlier question, it's of the lower end of the range there. It's predicated on that -- some macroeconomic headwinds perhaps that maybe out there. But we'r
componenttext: Yes, there's nothing specific that we are baking in. I think the standby -- in Tim's comments, to an earlier question, it's of the lower end of the range there. It's predicated on that -- some macroeconomic headwinds perhaps that maybe out there. But we're certainly not handicapping any particular segments in any particular way. We think it's an appropriate range of guidance provided, and I think as we said earlier, I certainly -- I don't recall the last time that I ran in a scheme and it was land in ranges. We've got a really strong operating business model in place now and we've been in a situation this past quarter, there are a number of activities going on and still putting a 4.5 points. So certainly feel pretty good about the opportunity ahead of us here in the next 90 days.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just finally on the Chengdu side, the decision I guess to make it as large as we see, is that something that you've been planning for a while or is that something that just demand tourism that you felt you need to expand the capacity to that size?
componenttext: Okay. Just finally on the Chengdu side, the decision I guess to make it as large as we see, is that something that you've been planning for a while or is that something that just demand tourism that you felt you need to expand the capacity to that size?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We've been exploring Western China site now for 2 years, and have pulled the trigger earlier this year after very diligent site selection and a negotiation process. So it's a result of some longer-term thinking. And we'll accommodate growth in the busines
componenttext: We've been exploring Western China site now for 2 years, and have pulled the trigger earlier this year after very diligent site selection and a negotiation process. So it's a result of some longer-term thinking. And we'll accommodate growth in the business. We're not starting with 2 million square feet that has the ability to ramp up to that level.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, a question for Tim and then a follow-up one for Forbes. Tim, when you mentioned and referred back to your Investor Day, you talked about how you still kind of see the same guidance there. I just wanted to clarify, were you meaning the percent growt
componenttext: First, a question for Tim and then a follow-up one for Forbes. Tim, when you mentioned and referred back to your Investor Day, you talked about how you still kind of see the same guidance there. I just wanted to clarify, were you meaning the percent growth by each segment or on the slide after that, you talked about a revenue level of 19 plus billion. I think you clarified it in some conferences to kind of $19.3 billion to $19.4 billion. I'm trying to figure out, are all of those still consistent? Or are those more focused on the growth because it seems like this year, the macro level have us coming out of the gate just a little bit slower? And then for Forbes. Forbes, you mentioned the higher tax rate. Can you help us understand what geographic area this is and is this reoccurring at these higher levels or is there some seasonality to the tax rate as we start to move ahead and build kind of beyond one quarter for the tax rate?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, first question. Are we talking about the absolute dollar level or the growth rates? And I think we're still very comfortable with the growth rates that we outlined. If it's -- if you're starting at a lower base, that will drive a somewhat lower
componenttext: Yes, Jim, first question. Are we talking about the absolute dollar level or the growth rates? And I think we're still very comfortable with the growth rates that we outlined. If it's -- if you're starting at a lower base, that will drive a somewhat lower top line. But I think more in terms of implicitly what that drives for earnings and EPS in FY '13, because we could be off of the revenue mix to a modest degree and still deliver outstanding EPS results will be consistent with what we talked about at the Analyst Meeting. So fair question. If you were modeling it, I'd model using the growth rates. And if you have a lower base, use the lower base. I think from an EPS standpoint, though we're still really excited about what we can deliver in FY '13. And the next 4, 5 years.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And Tim, with regards to the tax rates, what we're seeing is a higher proportion of our forward-looking income, coming from geographies such as China where there is a tax rate of 25%.And in India, our Indian facilities performing very well, actually, wh
componenttext:
And Tim, with regards to the tax rates, what we're seeing is a higher proportion of our forward-looking income, coming from geographies such as China where there is a tax rate of 25%.
And in India, our Indian facilities performing very well, actually, where those rates are in the mid-there, a little bit north of the mid-30% range. So we are seeing a little bit of a structural shift in terms of our income in the fourth quarter and certainly, as we move into the first couple of quarters of next fiscal year. So if for modeling purposes, I'd encourage a rate in the 22% range, something of that nature. And we'll see how that shifts or plays out as we move through the balance of '13 as we bring on capacity and as we bring on additional income streams in other parts of the globe.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

componenttext: I just had 2 questions. One on the solar customer. I think you gave some detail in the prepared remarks. But I wanted to get a sense of if you feel there's any risk to additional customers in the solar business solar and how much percentage of your business that is now?

componenttext: Sherri, to your first part, no, we don't believe we have any other risk in that particular industry. We've got a limited exposure there. In the last year, our revenue stream was considerably more so, it just was the natural shift in the solar industry and exposure to have come down and I suggest to be at those levels in '13. So no material in terms of overall revenue stream. It's pretty small actually and exposure in that regard. So I certainly don't expect any further charges that's associated with our activity in this area.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just turning back to the operating margin and thinking about the different segments, I mean, if I try to model it out based on the revenue growth and I assume flat margins for DMS and E&I, it suggest that HBS gets back to sort of you
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just turning back to the operating margin and thinking about the different segments, I mean, if I try to model it out based on the revenue growth and I assume flat margins for DMS and E&I, it suggest that HBS gets back to sort of your historical target range of 2%, 2.5%, which you haven't been in for quite some time. So is there an expectation that HBS falls back into the past historical target range and would you expect that moving forward?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't. We currently don't expect High Velocity to retrograde back to that to 2%, 2.5% range. What we have said, Sherri, is we will address the long-term targets 4 sectors on the September call. And we would address a more reasonable High Velocity margi
componenttext: We don't. We currently don't expect High Velocity to retrograde back to that to 2%, 2.5% range. What we have said, Sherri, is we will address the long-term targets 4 sectors on the September call. And we would address a more reasonable High Velocity margin at that time. We've also said at conferences and other institutes that we think it's -- we think it's acceptable to think about High Velocity being a 3% plus business for the foreseeable future.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Coreene, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Jabil Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.I would now like to turn the call ove
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Coreene, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Jabil Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
I would now like to turn the call over to your host, Beth Walters. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Welcome, everyone, to our third quarter of 2012 earnings call. Joining me today our President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on
componenttext:
Thank you very much. Welcome, everyone, to our third quarter of 2012 earnings call. Joining me today our President and CEO, Timothy Main; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.
This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section. Our third quarter press release and corresponding webcast slides are also available on our website. In these slides, you will find the financial information that we cover during this call. We ask that you follow the presentation with the slides on the website, beginning with Slide 2, our forward-looking statement.
During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements, including those regarding the anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected fourth quarter of fiscal 2012 net revenue and earnings results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2011, on subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and our other securities filings. Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Today's call will begin with our third quarter results, highlights and comments from Forbes Alexander as well as guidance on our fourth fiscal quarter of 2012. Tim Main will follow with some macroenvironment and Jabil-specific comments about our performance, our model and our current outlook. We'll then open it up to questions from call attendees.
I'll now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Beth. Hello, everyone. I ask you to refer to Slide 3. Our net revenue for the third quarter was $4.25 billion, an increase of 0.5% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $156.6 million or 3.7% of revenue, which compares to $152.5 mil
componenttext:
Thanks, Beth. Hello, everyone. I ask you to refer to Slide 3. Our net revenue for the third quarter was $4.25 billion, an increase of 0.5% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $156.6 million or 3.7% of revenue, which compares to $152.5 million of GAAP operating income on revenues of $4.28 billion or 3.6% in the same period the prior year.
Core operating income, excluding the amortization of intangibles, stock-based compensation and a distressed customer charge, increased 7.1% to $190.3 million and represents 4.5% of revenue. This compares to $177.8 million or 4.2% for the same period in the prior year. GAAP diluted earnings per share for the third quarter were $0.48, an increase of 2.1% over the prior year. Core diluted earnings per share was $0.64, an increase of 10.3% over the prior year.
Please note that our GAAP operating results were negatively impacted by $10.1 million during the quarter as the result of a distressed customer charge taken associated with the solar industry. The solar industry today operates in a difficult environment, with much uncertainty and continuing trade disputes with China. We are at significantly lower levels of production than we were in fiscal '11. We anticipate volumes in fiscal '13 to be somewhat similar. And although the demand environment is not robust, we do not anticipate any further charges.
Now I would ask you to refer to Slide 4 for a discussion of our segments. In the third quarter, our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew 22% on a year-over-year basis, driven largely by strength in our Specialized Services sector. Revenue was approximately $1.9 billion, representing 44% of total company revenue. Core operating income expanded 70 basis points to 6.5% of revenue. Revenue in the Enterprise & Infrastructure segment decreased 4% on a year-over-year basis, while exceeding our expectations in the quarter. The quarter saw strength in storage due to a large program ramp as a result of customer consolidation activity in our favor.
Revenue was approximately $1.3 billion, representing 31% of total company revenue. Core operating income for this segment expanded by 50 basis points sequentially to 2.2% of revenue. The High Velocity segment decreased 20%, excuse me, on a year-over-year basis, driven by continued weakness in handset volumes. Revenue was $1.1 billion, representing 25% of total company revenue in the quarter. Excluding our handset business, High Velocity is performing very well, as evidenced by year-over-year gains in set-top box, point of sale, printing and automotive. As a result of this mix, core operating income for the segment remained above our long-term expectations at 3.7% of revenue. During the quarter, there was only one 10% customer presiding in our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, while our top 10 customers comprised 60.2%.
I'll now ask you to refer to Slide 5 while I review some of our balance sheet and cash metrics. We're pleased with our working capital and operating cash flow performance in the quarter. Sales cycle improved by 3 days sequentially, inventory turns remained at 7, while cash flow generated from operations was $186 million. We ended the quarter with cash balances of $742 million. During the quarter, we repurchased some 1.5 million shares with a value of approximately $30 million. There was no impact to reported earnings per share in the quarter as a result of these repurchases. And $30 million remains outstanding on our current stock repurchase program.
EBITDA in the quarter expanded to $275 million or 6.5% of revenue, the highest level since the fourth fiscal quarter of 2005. Our net capital expenditures during the quarter were approximately $108 million. As I indicated on our March earnings call, we continue to expect capital expenditure levels for the second half of this fiscal year to be approximately $320 million. The majority of these expenditures were targeted within our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment, specifically associated with rapidly expanding capacity in our Specialized Services sector. As we exit the year, we should have doubled our square footage in Wuxi, China and have recently signed an agreement to establish a site in Chengdu, China. The ultimate available capacity up to the size of our Wuxi operations. The first phase of this expansion is scheduled to be completed during our first fiscal quarter 2013.
I now ask you to turn to Slide 6 for a summary, excuse me, of the quarter's performance. We're pleased with the operating performance in our third fiscal quarter. Core operating margin performance was 4.5%, the midpoint of our guidance, while revenues were below the midpoint of the range provided. Core operating income expanded 30 basis points on both a sequential and year-over-year basis, while EBITDA expanded 30 basis points sequentially and 50 basis points on a year-over-year basis. Our return on invested capital calculated on a GAAP net to income basis was 19%, while 24% on a core basis.
Finally, I ask you to refer to Slides 8 and 9, where I'd like to discuss our fourth quarter guidance. We expect revenue in our fourth fiscal quarter to be in the range of $4.1 billion to $4.35 billion. Core operating income is estimated to be in the range of $170 million to $200 million, and core operating margin in the range of 4.1% to 4.6%. Our core earnings per share is expected to be in the range of $0.54 to $0.66 per diluted share, and GAAP earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $0.43 to $0.55 per diluted share. This is based upon our diluted share count of approximately 212 million shares.
Based upon the current estimate of production, the tax rate on core operating income is expected to be in the low- to mid-20% range for the fourth fiscal quarter, reflecting a higher proportion of anticipated income from higher tax rate geographies.
Turning to our segments and year-on-year performance, the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to increase 17%. The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment is expected to decline 5% and finally, our High Velocity segment is expected to decline 22% on a year-over-year basis.
Thank you, and I'd now like to hand the call over to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Forbes. I'll make a few comments on present conditions and then longer-term perspectives. In the short term, we are managing through a period with many changes happening simultaneously. It is well documented that our mobility customer in the High
componenttext:
Thanks, Forbes. I'll make a few comments on present conditions and then longer-term perspectives. In the short term, we are managing through a period with many changes happening simultaneously. It is well documented that our mobility customer in the High Velocity sector has been under duress as they have grappled with declining sales and leadership changes while making preparations for a critical launch of an important new product platform.
This customer has publicly articulated their intent to drive higher performance and drive greater efficiency in their supply chain through consolidation of fewer, high-capability suppliers. Jabil has been selected as the go-forward partner and we expect to consolidate production regionally in Mexico and Hungary over the next 1 or 2 quarters. Future levels of production will be highly dependent on a number of factors within and outside of our control. However, we expect our total revenue with this customer will remain below the 10% level in our fourth fiscal quarter of 2012 and throughout fiscal 2013.
In order to support the number of new customers and rising demand, we are in the midst of a large-scale capacity expansion for Diversified Manufacturing Services. In addition to expanding existing sites, we have also broken ground on a new site in Chengdu, China. This new site is capable of supporting up to 2 million square feet of manufacturing capacity intended for our Specialized Services and other EMS business areas. Production from the new site is expected to commence by the end of this calendar year.
Margins in our Enterprise & Infrastructure sector expanded 50 basis points sequentially, as revenue increased 8%. While we expect revenue to be stable to slightly higher sequentially for the next several quarters, our expectations for growth are more muted now than 90 days ago. Counterbalancing lackluster end markets, we have earned additional market share with some customers and experienced inefficiencies in ramping production on incoming transfers over the course of our third fiscal quarter. These inefficiencies are expected to continue through at least part of FQ 4 before reaching the tier production efficiencies in FQ 1 of '13. In addition to ramping up new programs, we will look to take an appropriate level of cost reduction actions in order to return margins to our long-term targeted range.
Excluding our mobility customer in High Velocity, the balance of our High Velocity business is actually growing at acceptable return levels. Excluding the aforementioned mobility customer, we expect balance High Velocity revenue and income to increase over 15% in FY '12 over FY '11. While High Velocity is not a target growth area for Jabil, it does underscore that Jabil continues to be a cost-effective, trustworthy name for attractive customers in this business area. We are fast, flexible and competitive and we have the ability to compete in more ways and in more theaters than most of our competitors. Integration of our Telmar acquisition continues in our aftermarket Services business.
Additionally, AMS is innovating a number of new multi-country, multi-leader service strategies that are generating solid organic growth. The Telmar integration and the launch of these new service offerings or specific customers has had a negative impact on profit levels in FQ3 and is expected to show modest improvement in FQ4 of 2012. We look for AMS to lead the industry in innovation and service and for Jabil AMS to continue to widen it's lead over the competition.
Moving from the present to the future, we believe 2012 will be our third consecutive record year even though it will close on a more subdued note than we anticipated earlier this year. Jabil is building and grooming the business for strong income growth for years to come. Investments in Specialized Services, Health Care & Industrial, along with the sustained competitive position in traditional markets should lead to continuing high-quality growth in revenue and earnings for years to come.
In reality, superior long-term performance should be expected at Jabil. For example, as of 2011, there were 163 Fortune 500 companies with revenue over $16 billion a year. Not a single one of them posted higher growth in revenue, EBITDA and GAAP EPS than Jabil over the 17-year period since we went public in 1994. And since 2008, only 5 have reported higher growth than Jabil: Apple, Intel and 3 financial institutions: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo and Prudential. Finally, for the 10-year period from fiscal 2001 through fiscal 2011, Jabil has posted a GAAP EPS compound annual growth rate of 11.5%. There's always room for improvement, but that's not a bad track record considering all of the convulsive changes that have occurred over the past 10 years.
Thank you for listening, and we're now prepared to take your questions

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Amit, I think we're at a period where -- just to make things simple, of our 10 largest customers, we've had 2 customers this year with revenue year-over-year that's down about $1 billion. We have a customer with revenue that's up about $1 billion, and the
componenttext: Amit, I think we're at a period where -- just to make things simple, of our 10 largest customers, we've had 2 customers this year with revenue year-over-year that's down about $1 billion. We have a customer with revenue that's up about $1 billion, and the rest of the businesses doing pretty well growing at 5% to 10% depending on the business area. So I'd say that the revenue headwinds have a lot to do with a couple of customer-specific issues lack of the macro tailwind. I think end markets are relatively stable, but there isn't much of a tailwind. And in light of the circumstances that we're in today and the overall demand environment, I feel pretty good about having a flattish quarter this quarter with great spring loading of opportunity for outstanding growth in FY '13.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just get some -- if you just talk about the win relationship and given the fact you're actually picking up incremental share with them in fiscal '13, it sounds like. How do we think about the fiscal '13 objective you laid out at the Analyst
componenttext: And then maybe just get some -- if you just talk about the win relationship and given the fact you're actually picking up incremental share with them in fiscal '13, it sounds like. How do we think about the fiscal '13 objective you laid out at the Analyst Day, which I think assumed HVS would essentially be flat next year. Do we have to start thinking for a higher number in that segment? And also on the margin line, how do you think the 2%, 2.5% margin target shapes out in the segment?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's premature for us to handicap what the mobility customers' consolidation will mean to us in terms of prospective growth in FY '13. Having said that, we have reviewed in detail our FY '13 plans and still feel confident with what was presented a
componenttext: I think it's premature for us to handicap what the mobility customers' consolidation will mean to us in terms of prospective growth in FY '13. Having said that, we have reviewed in detail our FY '13 plans and still feel confident with what was presented at the Analyst Meeting, which was growth of 25% in MTG, 15% in other Diversified Manufacturing Services areas, 10% in Enterprise & Infrastructure and 0% in High Velocity. But I think we are -- I think in terms of how you should look at this, Amit, and the rest of the analyst community going forward, I think the granularity on revenue will be more difficult, particularly in short-term time horizons. But we have increasing level of confidence around our ability to deliver consistency and earnings on a long-term basis and certainly in annual buckets. So while the revenues may shift around a bit from what we presented at the Analyst Meeting, we feel very good about what that implies in terms of earnings for FY '13.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's not something we can discuss. I'm not trying to be unhelpful, Brian, I'd love to help you out, but there are -- there's always sensitive customers issues within those 3 areas. And I don't think it's actually that meaningful looking at it from
componenttext: Yes, that's not something we can discuss. I'm not trying to be unhelpful, Brian, I'd love to help you out, but there are -- there's always sensitive customers issues within those 3 areas. And I don't think it's actually that meaningful looking at it from an investor's perspective because the margin structure, the health of the customers, all that kind of stuff is just not that meaningful. I mean, we're delighted that even in a period where there's such macro uncertainty and lack of end market tailwinds that we've got Diversified Manufacturing Services, which we intend to rely on for our primary growth engine for the next 4, 5 years, growing within our targeted range of 20% to 30%. And I think the estimate is, Brian, that will be 25% for the full year, based on where we've guided. So I think that's pretty good. I -- what we talked about in the Analyst Meeting might be useful to reiterate a little bit. Healthcare & Industrial grew at a slower rate this year. I think we previewed that, actually it's the beginning of the year, the outset of the year that we think this would be the year in which we grow 7% to 8%, that may not be exactly that based on Q4 but the slower growth year. But with the pipeline of new product development opportunities, particularly in healthcare, we highlighted 20 to 21, 22 important new programs in health care, along with industrial, I think the SAG and solar demand has attenuated the growth in industrial, have actually had some very important new customer wins and program transfers in industrial. So while I look forward in FY '13, I think you'll see Industrial and Healthcare grow at a much healthier cliff, much closer to the low end of the 20% to 30% range. And we may choose to supplement that in certain areas with an acquisition some time in the close of this fiscal year or early next year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we're at 20 basis points light this quarter. There are some revenue growth that's not quite as robust and we've had some inefficiencies and product ramps, as I said. I think the revenue levels there will be sequentially positive, which gives us an o
componenttext: Well, we're at 20 basis points light this quarter. There are some revenue growth that's not quite as robust and we've had some inefficiencies and product ramps, as I said. I think the revenue levels there will be sequentially positive, which gives us an opportunity to drive margin, particularly if we can get after the cost side of it. We may need an extra quarter to get back to the targeted range, but I think we'll maintain a positive trajectory.

componenttext: First question on the Enterprise outlook. Can you just talk a little bit more granular, Tim, on what changed over the last 90 days in the end markets, and if any of the markets are still growing relative to your previous expectations? And then secondly, just on the expansion that you mentioned in Chengdu, can you talk a little bit more about exactly what's going in there? I think you ranged it around a couple of businesses, but what's driving it? And if I heard right, I think you said by the end of the calendar year, it's going to be in production and can you just sort of detail that a little bit more?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the Enterprise & Infrastructure, not a dramatic slowdown. In fact, some customers are actually expecting some revenue growth. I think earlier this year, Steven, we were thinking that the second half of calendar 2012 would be a little bit more rob
componenttext: Okay. On the Enterprise & Infrastructure, not a dramatic slowdown. In fact, some customers are actually expecting some revenue growth. I think earlier this year, Steven, we were thinking that the second half of calendar 2012 would be a little bit more robust enterprise & Infrastructure customers just because the spending levels have been so low. And typically, what we see is a pattern of underinvestment and in a macroenvironment that has at least some growth, that spending tends to bounce back and there's a catch-up period. I think that's going to happen again. I mean, that Enterprise & Infrastructure spending is necessary, strategic, important. I think the fiscal constraints that governments are in all around the world has resulted in very low levels of federal spending, government spending and big corporations are risk-averse right now. So I think spend rates have slowed down a little bit. Essentially that will bottom and rebound. And man, are we -- full of great customers out in that area. So we will definitely outperform when that bounces back. It's really on the margin a little bit. Again, we expect sequential revenue growth. We have won some new business in the Enterprise infrastructure area. Got a little bit of difficulty transferring them into our facilities but we'll get through that over the course of Q4. I'd say in terms of any other helpful color, storage has been a great business area for us and continues to be, that's probably lead in terms of being a robust business area for Jabil. That continues to be a good area for us. But we have great customers in networking and the telecom area as well. You mentioned Chengdu, I need to tread softly there because I can't highlight customers. That would preview individual customers, supply chain strategies and we're not in liberty to do that, and that's consistent with the company's long-term policy. So I'm not doing anything that's out of character for us, but you can bet there are sizable customers with significant requirements and we will -- we intend to be in production by the end of this calendar year. But we can put traditional business in Chengdu. We can put Specialized Services, AMS business, MTG business, all kinds of businesses in Chengdu. It is not being done as a -- I mean, it has the secondary benefit of being a cost edge against close to China and we may be able to use it in future periods. But it's really being put in place to support rising demand with multiple customers.

componenttext: Well, it goes without saying that we're in a uncertain macroenvironment. I think we're influenced partly by that environment. There's no reason for us to be overly aggressive with our confidence about the macroenvironment. That's outside of our control. We did highlight a number of changes occurring simultaneously in High Velocity and Diversified Manufacturing Services and Aftermarket Services. A lot of things for us to focus on this quarter, Wamsi. If we execute very well, I think we'll do well in a macro environment that doesn't tip over. If the macro situation weakens significantly and we fail to execute, that will drive us to the low end. But I think it's a period where a little bit wider range is very appropriate given the number of changes and the highly dynamic environment that we're in today.

componenttextpreview: I'm glad you highlighted it, Amitabh, that it's been over 2 years since we've had -- [indiscernible] of our operating margin. That's very helpful. We appreciate that. And I might as well just mention again, that 6.5% EBITDA is the highest level since the
componenttext: I'm glad you highlighted it, Amitabh, that it's been over 2 years since we've had -- [indiscernible] of our operating margin. That's very helpful. We appreciate that. And I might as well just mention again, that 6.5% EBITDA is the highest level since the fourth quarter 2005, in any case. So, I mean, really it's just a matter of if revenue is far less than we though and we struggle with some of the operational challenges that we have this quarter, it could drive it to that lower level. Now we have not been at the low-end of our operating margin guidance in my flawed memory for a long time. So even this quarter where our EPS and revenue levels were a little bit mixed, our margins were outstanding. And as Diversified Manufacturing Services continues to grow as a percentage of overall business, I think our margin profile will continue to be attractive. But there is 4.1% at the low-end and it's tough to kind of handicap in the what downside scenarios could happen over the course of the quarter, but if we require quite a few of those downside risk to align together and then that's possible. Nothing in particular though. If you think about it, a particular event that we're trying to handicap in.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And if I can follow up with Tim, in the Material Technology Group, can you talk about the impact of available capacity in that group? Obviously, there's a lot of focus on one big customer but outside of that, are you capacity constrained such that as you
componenttext: And if I can follow up with Tim, in the Material Technology Group, can you talk about the impact of available capacity in that group? Obviously, there's a lot of focus on one big customer but outside of that, are you capacity constrained such that as you look to diversify or win new business with new customers, would that impact you in the coming quarters or if you could frame that, that would be helpful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're at high levels of capacity utilization in our MTG group, we have a wide range of sites, such as from Shenzhen, to Suzhou and Nanjing and Tianjin, Wuxi, Kwai Chung and soon to be Chengdu. So we have a lot of options. The management team is, in that g
componenttext: We're at high levels of capacity utilization in our MTG group, we have a wide range of sites, such as from Shenzhen, to Suzhou and Nanjing and Tianjin, Wuxi, Kwai Chung and soon to be Chengdu. So we have a lot of options. The management team is, in that group, trying to keep the capacity insulated customer-to-customer, so the customers don't need to worry about a lack of resource. More focused on their, particularly, production areas. So I think they do a very good job of managing that. That's clearly a growth area for us, and we're adding resources and capacity to support a number of customers. But we try and keep them insulated as well as we can. Jabil's has got a long history of the workcell business model and keeping operational teams separate so that each customer can rely on us to focus completely on their production requirements and support their needs through the ups and downs of unscheduled changes. So I don't know if that's helpful or not, but it's probably about the extent of what I can say on that, Craig.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. No, that helps. If I can just -- a quick follow-up with Forbes on the buyback program. If you look at it today versus a year ago when you guys bought back I think $200 million last summer, any constraints on the balance sheet or anything to think ab
componenttext: Sure. No, that helps. If I can just -- a quick follow-up with Forbes on the buyback program. If you look at it today versus a year ago when you guys bought back I think $200 million last summer, any constraints on the balance sheet or anything to think about in terms of capital allocation in the half back that would constrain the ability to buy back more stock?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. No constraints from a capital perspective. Our balance sheet is in terrific shape. Should we wish to do anything more of that to EBITDA this quarter as we exit this year, that will be running by 1.5x, towards that level of about $1.7 billion. So essen
componenttext: No. No constraints from a capital perspective. Our balance sheet is in terrific shape. Should we wish to do anything more of that to EBITDA this quarter as we exit this year, that will be running by 1.5x, towards that level of about $1.7 billion. So essentially what that means is we're going somewhere between $1.5 billion and $2 billion of debt capacity available to us. So fairly no constraints in that perspective. We'll point out, we're continuing to invest for growth. I referenced $320 million of capital expenditures, in the back half of the fiscal year. And we have talked about some $500 million of CapEx for next fiscal year. So even with those levels and the cash we're producing, certainly, we have a real comfort with how our balance sheet looks.

componenttext: I -- in my prepared remarks, Sean, I mentioned a single mobility customer in our High Velocity sector intends to consolidate to fewer high-capability suppliers. Jabil has been selected as one of those go-forward partners, and that, that production will be consolidated regionally in Mexico and Hungary, where we are already in production for that customer.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the assembly side, we're just talking that action. Okay. And then separately, on -- I had -- I didn't quite get all the comments around the Telmar. Did I hear that there were some customer issues? Was looking to see if I can get a little bit m
componenttext: Okay. So on the assembly side, we're just talking that action. Okay. And then separately, on -- I had -- I didn't quite get all the comments around the Telmar. Did I hear that there were some customer issues? Was looking to see if I can get a little bit more clarity around what happened with Telmar in the quarter and how to think of that business as we progress into Q4 and moving forward.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: What I mentioned is the integration of the Telmar acquisition continues in AMS, and AMS is also -- and there are some expenses associated with that. There's also a number of new service offerings that our multi-country and multilayer that AMS has introduc
componenttext: What I mentioned is the integration of the Telmar acquisition continues in AMS, and AMS is also -- and there are some expenses associated with that. There's also a number of new service offerings that our multi-country and multilayer that AMS has introduced for specific customers, and that's been a drag on earnings in FQ3, and we'll start to improve in FQ4. Telmar, I'd say, that we're delighted with the acquisition overall. It is contributing to our service offering for telecommunications customers in a very deep and meaningful way, and I would expect FY '13 to be much improved in terms of AMS's outlook and their ability to grow in a new vertical on an exciting new area. And so we're really delighted with it. Short-term, we're going to the integration process, and so the accretion levels aren't as -- aren't what they'll be in a 1 or 2 quarters, but we are absolutely delighted with that acquisition and already seeing synergies develop between Telmar and our AMS Group.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And once you're into that period where you're fully integrated and you're able to actually capitalize on the efficiencies you're hoping for from either a top line growth perspective or from a margin standpoint, does that look to be materializing, again, a
componenttext: And once you're into that period where you're fully integrated and you're able to actually capitalize on the efficiencies you're hoping for from either a top line growth perspective or from a margin standpoint, does that look to be materializing, again, a few quarters out the degree that you anticipated in doing the deal or is there actually some better -- stronger benefits that you may actually capitalize on?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, honestly, I'd say that it's been a little bit lighter than expected in the first couple of quarters of ownership. But that prospectively, it will exceed its original business plan. So we are starting to realize the revenue synergies that we expected.
componenttext: Yes, honestly, I'd say that it's been a little bit lighter than expected in the first couple of quarters of ownership. But that prospectively, it will exceed its original business plan. So we are starting to realize the revenue synergies that we expected. So sort of it's been slower getting out of the gate than we expected but we actually think it could be bigger than expected in FY '13.

componenttext: So, Tim, you talked about that the growth rates for FY '13 sticking to comments you made at your Analyst Day, and as you look at that pipeline and understanding certainly visibility and demand is limited here, do you see some of those new business opportunities kicking in, in the November quarter or is that going to be more back-end loaded towards the back half of your FY '13?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll look at quarterly guidance our September call. But I would imagine we start to see benefits in our first fiscal quarter, probably that's fair to say. And the year that we guided -- that we provided a framework, so thinking about FY '13, that we
componenttext: Yes, we'll look at quarterly guidance our September call. But I would imagine we start to see benefits in our first fiscal quarter, probably that's fair to say. And the year that we guided -- that we provided a framework, so thinking about FY '13, that we should have a good start in the first fiscal quarter. The only caveat to that is we premise that on GDP growth that's positive and low single-digit, but if the world tips over from a macro standpoint, that's probably not going to be deliverable. But based on what we see today and what we have on our hands, FY '13 should get off to a pretty good start.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012

componenttext: And then same thing on the margin headwinds that you talked about, some of the new program ramps, customer transitions, Telmar, et cetera, do you also see some margin headwinds on program ramps in the Materials group as you're ramping new products for customers in the next quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't provide any margin guidance or color on MTG that's within Specialized Services within DMS and all of the publishers in the DMS area. But any time you're ramping new production, you're less efficient on the front end of that ramp up and as you get
componenttext: We don't provide any margin guidance or color on MTG that's within Specialized Services within DMS and all of the publishers in the DMS area. But any time you're ramping new production, you're less efficient on the front end of that ramp up and as you get to more mature levels of production, you expect to hit targeted rates of return. And that's pretty much true across-the-board. That's manufacturing is manufacturing regardless of the activity.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then just the last question, if I may, just regarding the mobility customer. Some of your competitors have walked away from that business and have talked about returns in profitability goals below their targets. Have you talked to that customer? Have
componenttext: And then just the last question, if I may, just regarding the mobility customer. Some of your competitors have walked away from that business and have talked about returns in profitability goals below their targets. Have you talked to that customer? Have you -- do you have new contracts in place to ensure that you're going to meet profitability and returns goals?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, that's an existing customer, it's not a customer that I deal with everyday. But our executive staff and key people in our executive staff are in very close contact. And we're kind of appalled at the way people walk away from customers. We believe th
componenttext: Well, that's an existing customer, it's not a customer that I deal with everyday. But our executive staff and key people in our executive staff are in very close contact. And we're kind of appalled at the way people walk away from customers. We believe that if you do business with a customer and they rely on you for a set of services, you should continue to do that through good times and bad. It's a fundamental premise of being in our business. Our customers rely on us to provide, in many cases, 100% of their manufacturing supply chain infrastructure. They cannot deliver products without us. So to the extent that you have a rational economic model and rational risk and reward embedded in contractual agreements and the rest of that kind of stuff, there's no reason ever to walk away from a customer. And so I think that people think about stock and how they trade sometimes more than they think about what makes up a good customer and what doesn't. And we'll see where this goes. But we think that continuing to be a supplier in this regard and enjoy the benefit of that relationship and the investment that's been made in relationship and the opportunity to continue in production and have adequate returns and a balance between risk and reward is much better for our company and much better for our shareholders than walking away from it.

componenttext: Yes, I think, certainly, we've commented in the prepared remarks that we're not seeing the revenue growth that perhaps we saw 90 days ago. So we still believe that the focus and target is within our range over the next couple of 3 quarters here. So if we don't see those benefits from a revenue lift, we'll appropriately shift the cost structure. So certainly, it will be around about those levels, perhaps a little bit higher depending upon the revenue stream you see as we move through the next 90, 120 days or so.

componenttext: Yes, there's nothing specific that we are baking in. I think to stand by Tim's comments, to an earlier question, that lower end of the range there is predicated on that -- some macroeconomic headwinds perhaps that maybe out there. But we're certainly not handicapping any particular segments in any particular way. We think it's an appropriate range of guidance provided, and I think as we said earlier, I certainly -- I don't recall the last time that I ran in a scheme and that was around the ranges. We've got a really strong operating business model in place now and we've been in a situation this past quarter, there are a number of activities going on and we're still putting up 4.5 points. So certainly feel pretty good about the opportunity ahead of us here in the next 90 days.

componenttext: We've been exploring Western China site now for 2 years, and have pulled the trigger earlier this year after very diligent site selection and a negotiation process. So it's the result of some longer-term thinking. And we'll accommodate growth in the business. If we're not starting with 2 million square feet, it has the ability to ramp up to that level.

componenttextpreview: First, a question for Tim and then a follow-up one for Forbes. Tim, when you mentioned and referred back to your Investor Day, you talked about you still kind of see the same guidance there. I just wanted to clarify, were you meaning the percent growth by
componenttext: First, a question for Tim and then a follow-up one for Forbes. Tim, when you mentioned and referred back to your Investor Day, you talked about you still kind of see the same guidance there. I just wanted to clarify, were you meaning the percent growth by each segment or on the slide after that, you talked about a revenue level of 19 plus billion. I think since then you've clarified at some conferences to kind of $19.3 billion to $19.4 billion. I'm just trying to figure out, are all of those still consistent? Or is it more that's focused on the growth because it seems like this year, the macro levels have us coming out of the gate just a little bit slower? And then for Forbes. Forbes, you mentioned the higher tax rate. Can you help us understand kind of what geographic areas this is and is it reoccurring at these higher levels or is there some seasonality to the tax rate as we start to look ahead and build kind of beyond one quarter for the tax rate?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, third question. Are we talking about the absolute dollar level or the growth rates? And I think we're still very comfortable with the growth rates that we outlined. If it's -- if you're starting at a lower base, that will drive a somewhat lower
componenttext: Yes, Jim, third question. Are we talking about the absolute dollar level or the growth rates? And I think we're still very comfortable with the growth rates that we outlined. If it's -- if you're starting at a lower base, that will drive a somewhat lower top line. But I think more in terms of implicitly what that drives for earnings and EPS in FY '13, because we could be off in the revenue mix to a modest degree and still deliver outstanding EPS results will be consistent with what we talked about at the Analyst Meeting. So a fair question. If you were modeling and I'd model, I'd model using the growth rates. And if you have a lower base, use the lower base. I think from an EPS standpoint, though, we're still really excited about what we can deliver in FY '13 and the next 4, 5 years.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And Tim, with regard to the tax rates, what we're seeing is a higher proportion of our forward-looking income coming from geographies such as China, where there is a tax rate of 25%.And in India, our Indian facility is performing very well, actually, wh
componenttext:
And Tim, with regard to the tax rates, what we're seeing is a higher proportion of our forward-looking income coming from geographies such as China, where there is a tax rate of 25%.
And in India, our Indian facility is performing very well, actually, where those rates are in the mid-30s, a little bit north of the mid-30%. So we are seeing a little bit of a structural shift in terms of our income in the fourth quarter and certainly, as we move into the first couple of quarters of next fiscal year. So for modeling purposes, I'd encourage a rate in the 22% range, something of that nature. And we'll see how that shifts or plays out as we move through the balance of '13 as we bring on capacity and as we bring on additional income streams in other parts of the globe.

componenttext: Sherri, to your first point, no, we don't believe we have any other risk in that particular industry. We've got a limited exposure there. componenttext: We don't -- we currently don't expect High Velocity to retrograde back to that to 2%, 2.5% range. headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2012
