headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: The business is growing at about 9%, 10% year-over-year. So the pipeline of opportunities are good there. They have extended their business into some very advanced logistics and forward logistics capabilities, taking on new business areas in places like t
componenttext: The business is growing at about 9%, 10% year-over-year. So the pipeline of opportunities are good there. They have extended their business into some very advanced logistics and forward logistics capabilities, taking on new business areas in places like the African continent and other areas that are very challenging, very IT-intensive and are really stretching their capabilities. We think long term, they will pay -- those efforts will pay really extraordinary dividends. We're active as always in looking for acquisitions and other opportunities to build capabilities there. But right now, they're played as very -- with the customers and pipeline of opportunity that they have on an organic basis.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: So looks like you're guiding revenue down about 5% sequentially, EPS down about 12% if I use the midpoint of the guidance. So can you just talk about the operating margin decline that you're looking for in the February quarter and 20 basis points or so, h
componenttext: So looks like you're guiding revenue down about 5% sequentially, EPS down about 12% if I use the midpoint of the guidance. So can you just talk about the operating margin decline that you're looking for in the February quarter and 20 basis points or so, how much of that is being driven by the mix shift away from DMS and how much would you attribute to margin declines within some of your segments, and if you could maybe just give some directional color on margins by segment, that would be helpful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's pretty tough to isolate how much of it is just deleveraging on the revenue being down, and how much of it is associated by segment because it's kind of tough to pick apart. It's really very consistent if you look back over our history, it's actually
componenttext: It's pretty tough to isolate how much of it is just deleveraging on the revenue being down, and how much of it is associated by segment because it's kind of tough to pick apart. It's really very consistent if you look back over our history, it's actually a very low level of seasonality in terms of being 5% down for the last 3, 4 years have been low single to 5% kind of seasonality. So a lot less than it's historically been. And the level of income that's coming out of the model for Q2 is very consistent with deleveraging, probably a little bit less than what we've seen historically. No, historically, we've seen something in the order of $0.15 to $0.20 on the dollar. And in this case, it's less than that. So I don't think it should be surprising from a deleveraging standpoint. Directionally, in terms of margins for the business, I said on the last conference call and I just reiterate that here a little bit, we see that Enterprise & Infrastructure and High Velocity margins -- lessening in the 3% range, notwithstanding the fact that they have different long-term targets, at least in the next 3 to 5 quarters. I think we'd expect the average of the 2 to be in the 3% range, maybe a little bit better as we exit that period. But we're kind of an average of 3%. And I think that in terms of the Diversified Manufacturing Services, if you look forward a few quarters, we should be able to average 6% or a little bit better. So that would model to something in the mid-4s for the company overall, which we think is a reasonable way to look at it beyond Q2. So looking at Q3, Q4, maybe Q1 of 2014.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just a quick follow-up, Tim, on the -- I didn't hear you allude to the EPS growth for fiscal '13. I think last quarter we talked about 5% to 10% growth. So I don't know if that's something you're still expecting or if that's off the table. I think y
componenttext: Okay. Just a quick follow-up, Tim, on the -- I didn't hear you allude to the EPS growth for fiscal '13. I think last quarter we talked about 5% to 10% growth. So I don't know if that's something you're still expecting or if that's off the table. I think you need to generate about 55% of the year in the second half. So just thought I would check on that.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we're not pulling away from the 5% to 10% although I'd say that based on the fact that first half of the year is about where we thought it be that we probably trend more towards the low end of that 5% to 10% range.
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we're not pulling away from the 5% to 10% although I'd say that based on the fact that first half of the year is about where we thought it be that we probably trend more towards the low end of that 5% to 10% range.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Amitabh Passi with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Amitabh Passi with UBS.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. Forbes, maybe just an appreciation of why the turnaround or improvement in E&I margins appears to be taking longer, revenue seem to be holding up relatively well. So I was hoping you could maybe just touch on that. And then for
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Forbes, maybe just an appreciation of why the turnaround or improvement in E&I margins appears to be taking longer, revenue seem to be holding up relatively well. So I was hoping you could maybe just touch on that. And then for High Velocity, as we move into the February quarter, one of your mobile customers will be ramping. Should we expect operating margin to stay above the 3% range or do you think we could probably see the operating margins in the high 2s?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. How are you doing? In regards to the E&I margins, I actually think we're on track. We -- we put the team in place from High Velocity, and exploiting some of our High Velocity capabilities. So there in the process of consolidating resources,
componenttext: This is Mark. How are you doing? In regards to the E&I margins, I actually think we're on track. We -- we put the team in place from High Velocity, and exploiting some of our High Velocity capabilities. So there in the process of consolidating resources, managing cost-containment, driving lowest cost solutions, optimizing working capital and improving operational efficiencies, but at the same time taking great care of the customers and providing good customer service. As we have talked about recently on the road we feel optimistic about getting to the 3% with little or no wind in our back as far as revenue recovery, to the extent we get some type of macroeconomic recovery that will help that much more.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then just on HVS margins as we look at the February quarter?
componenttext: And then just on HVS margins as we look at the February quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean directionally, the -- as we look into the February quarter, we've experienced some weakness in printing and set-top box as we've gone through the first quarter and we've seen some similar patterns as we move into Q2 with some seasonal adjustme
componenttext: Yes, I mean directionally, the -- as we look into the February quarter, we've experienced some weakness in printing and set-top box as we've gone through the first quarter and we've seen some similar patterns as we move into Q2 with some seasonal adjustment there. Some strength in handset, we can't discuss particular customers plans there, but obviously we have a -- a customer within High Velocity that clearly looking to launch product sometime during our second fiscal quarter. We'll see how that plays out. But we have seen some drift down in the margin just as that handset content increases within relative scale in our High Velocity. So depending where those volumes goes, so I would say to be consistent to be down a little bit depending on the levels of handset volumes we see sellthrough in Q2.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012

componenttext: Could you be specific about that number or is it more than 15%?

componenttext: We said we have 1 10% customer. And our top 10 customers are pretty consistent actually, roundabout 60%, 61%.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the E&I segment, where you continue to see some good growth there relative to the end markets obviously, being weak, how much of that is on the new program ramps versus what you're seeing from your customers in terms of end demand and if
componenttext: Okay. And then on the E&I segment, where you continue to see some good growth there relative to the end markets obviously, being weak, how much of that is on the new program ramps versus what you're seeing from your customers in terms of end demand and if you could be specific about the new program ramps or pipeline within that business, breaking down into the various segments of that industry.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just answer that in general terms. I think that most of what we're seeing on E&I in the early half of fiscal year '13 and carrying to the back half of the year winds that we realized mid- to end of fiscal year '12, the market conditions have
componenttext: Yes, I would just answer that in general terms. I think that most of what we're seeing on E&I in the early half of fiscal year '13 and carrying to the back half of the year winds that we realized mid- to end of fiscal year '12, the market conditions have been quite tough in that entire sector. The one good thing is we continue to serve some of the best brands, whether it be in storage, networking or telecom. But what we are seeing is if there's any uptick, the carriers and the NXP's are starting to spend some level of CapEx for network and infrastructure expansion especially around the 4G and the LTE area. As far as specific program is our whatnot, I'd rather keep it at a general level.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on that, Mark, relative to the pricing environment, we obviously, saw in the junior firm and the influxes news top from other AMS guys about a little bit more pricing pressure. Obviously, a tough market to begin with. Are
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on that, Mark, relative to the pricing environment, we obviously, saw in the junior firm and the influxes news top from other AMS guys about a little bit more pricing pressure. Obviously, a tough market to begin with. Are you starting to see some more pricing pressure on these new deals?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't characterize it as new pricing pressure. We've been in that market a long time and we're always under pretty intense pricing pressures. So as I've alluded to earlier, I think we've got -- I think in Tim's prepared statements High Velocity PlayB
componenttext: I wouldn't characterize it as new pricing pressure. We've been in that market a long time and we're always under pretty intense pricing pressures. So as I've alluded to earlier, I think we've got -- I think in Tim's prepared statements High Velocity PlayBook. What Tim is alluding to there is that we're taking some of our consumer type High Velocity capabilities, again around cost containment and optimizing working capital and consolidating resources, et cetera, et cetera, to be sure that we cannot only offer competitive pricing but get reasonable returns to get us to the 3% margin range by the end of the year.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes your next question comes from the line of Steven Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes your next question comes from the line of Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First of all, just in terms of new programs, just some clear, doesn't sound like you're talking about any other new program wins in the last couple of months helping this year's revenues. Have you seen any -- is there anything you'd headlig
componenttext: Two questions. First of all, just in terms of new programs, just some clear, doesn't sound like you're talking about any other new program wins in the last couple of months helping this year's revenues. Have you seen any -- is there anything you'd headlight in terms of momentum since the last quarter? And then specifically with that, can you talk a little bit about your ability to maybe diversify in Specialized Services away from just your 1 largest customer if you have any success there? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Which segment in the first part of your question, which segment are you referring to?
componenttext: Which segment in the first part of your question, which segment are you referring to?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just in general, Tim, just any kind of new program commentary just in general beyond what we've talked about.
componenttext: Just in general, Tim, just any kind of new program commentary just in general beyond what we've talked about.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little too diverse and dispersed to really characterize any major new programs that we've won. Some of the areas in our business were actually included from talking about new wins, but we feel good about it being a growth year. I think most people
componenttext: Yes, a little too diverse and dispersed to really characterize any major new programs that we've won. Some of the areas in our business were actually included from talking about new wins, but we feel good about it being a growth year. I think most people would be looking for a top line growth this year. We're off to a really a fabulous start. So in terms of FY '13 over FY '12, it should be a good year. Mark alluded to an Enterprise infrastructure at least, wins that were secured in FY '12 continuing FY '13 revenues. So in Specialized Services, we do have an aftermarket Services business there that's growing. That's a component of Specialized Services. Our MTG group does have a high level of concentration, although we do business with -- we do business with virtually every major mobility company in the world today. So that revenue is a little bit more diverse than what may be people think. It's expanding into areas, other areas of Consumer Electronics, optics and health care, which we hope to accelerate in the near future. We -- then within customers, it's always objective of the company to diversify within each major customer. So there's a quite a bit of program and product diversity within our MTG group. I think people tend to think about that as very one-dimensional in terms of product and we participate in a broad range of products over 25, 30 different programs and literally hundreds of different part numbers. So that stream of value is quite a bit more diverse in terms of product categories and what folks have typically associated with it. So...

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Now, I appreciate that. That's very helpful. And then just a quick follow-up, just to be clear, you guys have had some Jabil-specific issues that have affected the margins over the last few quarters, but if I understood the commentary correctly, there's s
componenttext: Now, I appreciate that. That's very helpful. And then just a quick follow-up, just to be clear, you guys have had some Jabil-specific issues that have affected the margins over the last few quarters, but if I understood the commentary correctly, there's some investments going on in E&I but generally speaking as we look at the margins for the rest of the year, we're basically looking at margins being driven by revenues quarter-to-quarter changes in revenues. Or are there other things we should factor in?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, for Q2, I think you just have to take it for what it is. It's revenue deleveraging and still looking at a growth year for Jabil. So that would imply that second half of the year will be very good from a revenue and margin standpoint. At least that's
componenttext: Well, for Q2, I think you just have to take it for what it is. It's revenue deleveraging and still looking at a growth year for Jabil. So that would imply that second half of the year will be very good from a revenue and margin standpoint. At least that's the way we see it today. And I think we will see some -- particularly if we get some tailwind in the Healthcare & Instrumentation and Industrial & Clean Tech areas that's stabilized and start to improve a little bit, that the DMS margins might start with a 6 in the second half of the year and between the E&I and High Velocity segments, if we averaged 3, that would imply operating margins for the company overall in the mid-4s. By the end of the year, based on growth rates, we should see Diversified Manufacturing Services become 50% of our business.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your DMS segment margins improved nicely relative to last quarter. Tim, can you give us some sense of what percent of capacity is being ramped up so far or maybe which inning you're in the ramps in Specialized Services, such that is it like realistic to t
componenttext: Your DMS segment margins improved nicely relative to last quarter. Tim, can you give us some sense of what percent of capacity is being ramped up so far or maybe which inning you're in the ramps in Specialized Services, such that is it like realistic to think that exiting next quarter, the drag from the ongoing ramps will be entirely behind you?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're in a kind of a continuous state of capacity expansion. Forbes mentioned CapEx trending towards the high end of the $500 million range, which means it will be adding capacity throughout the year. So we're at very high levels of utilization. We will b
componenttext:
We're in a kind of a continuous state of capacity expansion. Forbes mentioned CapEx trending towards the high end of the $500 million range, which means it will be adding capacity throughout the year. So we're at very high levels of utilization. We will be building additional capacity, all of which is in Specialized Services but fundamentally, the vast majority of it in the Diversified Manufacturing Services. So in terms of the drag, I think a lot of the interruptions that we highlighted in our Q4 call started to decline over the course of Q1 and we feel much better about the position that we're in today. I think margins would've been better in DMS if we have not seen a fairly significant decline in Clean Tech and instrumentation business, which is very understandable, given the dynamics and particularly when you start thinking about renewable energy and Smart Grid metering, which tend to be government and subsidy related.
So I think as that stabilizes and we start to improve margins in the health care and industrial areas that the overall DMS margin picture to improve.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. And just a follow-up, you mentioned I think in your answer to the last question that you could get to 6% DMS margins in the back half.But could you get their even if your levels of revenue can be sort of in the Healthcare & Instrumentation
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. And just a follow-up, you mentioned I think in your answer to the last question that you could get to 6% DMS margins in the back half.
But could you get their even if your levels of revenue can be sort of in the Healthcare & Instrumentation and Industrial & Clean Tech remain at levels where they are today?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that's possible. I mean, we'll have to see how things go. We have growth in health care and industrial. Actually, if you isolate the health care only business, it's actually very stable, and we're positioned for some growth. And at the same is tru
componenttext: I think that's possible. I mean, we'll have to see how things go. We have growth in health care and industrial. Actually, if you isolate the health care only business, it's actually very stable, and we're positioned for some growth. And at the same is true with Healthcare & Instrumentation of the industrial business, offbeat if you isolate Clean Tech from the industrial area, the industrial business has been very stable and poised for growth for the balance of the year. So we just kind of need the Instrumentation and Clean Tech areas to be stable. We don't need to grow, we just need to stop eroding to the extent that they did in the last quarter and then we'll see the Industrial and Health Care business grow and that will be accretive to the overall business.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Just a follow-up on the capacity, maybe another way to think about it is how much square footage have you been adding for DMS, I guess over the past 12 months at the end of this CapEx cycle, how much will square footage increase? And then t
componenttext: Two questions. Just a follow-up on the capacity, maybe another way to think about it is how much square footage have you been adding for DMS, I guess over the past 12 months at the end of this CapEx cycle, how much will square footage increase? And then the second question is with the buyback complete, what kind of prices are you looking to do another buyback here during the remainder of the year?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure how many square feet we've added. It's about to accommodate $500 million worth of stuff. I'm not being obtuse on purpose. I really -- I just don't know offhand, and I'm not sure that's a metric that will be valuable in any ways. But we're add
componenttext: I'm not sure how many square feet we've added. It's about to accommodate $500 million worth of stuff. I'm not being obtuse on purpose. I really -- I just don't know offhand, and I'm not sure that's a metric that will be valuable in any ways. But we're adding a lot of space. Forbes, do want to address that?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say we completed the stock repurchase. Certainly, at this juncture, no immediate plans to increase that or look for additional repurchase authorization. But we're well-positioned in terms of our cash generation this year. I still expect about $1
componenttext: Yes, I'd say we completed the stock repurchase. Certainly, at this juncture, no immediate plans to increase that or look for additional repurchase authorization. But we're well-positioned in terms of our cash generation this year. I still expect about $1 billion of cash flow. As we said earlier, we now expect our CapEx to be at the $500 million level. But we wanted to continue to manage the balance sheet conservatively as we move forward here, and make sure we do have liquidity available to continue to address where we think it's appropriate to do that. Enhancing our capabilities via acquisition or continued on this really good organic growth path we're on.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess with the $500 million, does that give you breathing room in terms of utilization within DMS? Are you still going to be kind of or running up against that?
componenttext: I guess with the $500 million, does that give you breathing room in terms of utilization within DMS? Are you still going to be kind of or running up against that?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I think that will -- once we deploy -- I mean, that would certainly give us some breathing room. Obviously, we're laying down additional square footage. We top of a couple of quarters go about expansion in Chengdu, with up to 2 million square feet. We
componenttext: So I think that will -- once we deploy -- I mean, that would certainly give us some breathing room. Obviously, we're laying down additional square footage. We top of a couple of quarters go about expansion in Chengdu, with up to 2 million square feet. We don't have this juncture plan on building the full 2 million. But certainly, we'd expect perhaps 1/2 of that as we exit the end of '13, we'll see how that plays. But still, there will be some capacity and we review that as we move through the fiscal year as to demand patterns we're seeing there.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Suva with Citi.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: When we look at your guidance and when we're talking in the February quarter year-over-year and now we're looking at year-over-year kind of remove to seasonality. Can you help us understand why EPS is not growing yet sales is growing, and the DMS is a muc
componenttext: When we look at your guidance and when we're talking in the February quarter year-over-year and now we're looking at year-over-year kind of remove to seasonality. Can you help us understand why EPS is not growing yet sales is growing, and the DMS is a much bigger part of your company? Is still yield issues within DMS? And if so, when you talk about 5% to 10% EPS growth this year, if my math is correct, that would be materially second half ramp, is that correct? And how should we think about how we can get from not year-over-year EPS growth right now, but yet such a big increase in the second half of the year. And my follow-up question, which is probably for Forbes, is your use of cash, stock buyback, you've finished it. You did quite a bit looking ahead CapEx, up a little bit. But is your plan use for cash now more centered around M&A, engineering, talent, CapEx, dividend? Help us better understand your, for cash because you're looking at a quite healthy situation.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Yes, I think year-over-year when we look at the DMS margins, they're down about 90 basis points. That's -- we're not pleased with that. We'd like to see that be in a higher register in the 6 range for sure at least. A lot of that is investmen
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. Yes, I think year-over-year when we look at the DMS margins, they're down about 90 basis points. That's -- we're not pleased with that. We'd like to see that be in a higher register in the 6 range for sure at least. A lot of that is investments in AMS, and the aforementioned headwinds that we're seeing in the Clean Tech and instrumentation area, our Specialized Services area's actually doing relatively well over year-over-year. So -- and again, I think we'll see marginal improvement in that area in the second half of the year. So -- now and I think we're really pleased with the 50 basis point improvement in that area quarter-on-quarter. Now our targeted range is 5.5, 7, and we're at 5.8 and a little bit better improvement and we'll see 6s again.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of the cash flow, Jim, I think you hit the nail on the head there. We're in a really strong position from a cash generation perspective, and as I said to previous comments, our main focus with that cash generation is to ensure liquidity to focus
componenttext:
In terms of the cash flow, Jim, I think you hit the nail on the head there. We're in a really strong position from a cash generation perspective, and as I said to previous comments, our main focus with that cash generation is to ensure liquidity to focus on what has been -- in this macroeconomic backdrop, impressive growth organically and also from an engineering talent perspective, from an acquisition perspective, should we feel we need to further expand our capabilities or enhance the revenue stream.
That's our key focus. We are committed to our dividend as it sits today, and we'll see how the balance of the year goes in terms of that cash generation. But we feel really good about the position we're in.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Hannan with Needham & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Hannan with Needham & Company.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Quick question around -- there have been a number of comments out there about reduced orders at your biggest customer and really based on bottlenecks within the supply chain. I haven't really heard that addressed or referenced too much during the call, an
componenttext: Quick question around -- there have been a number of comments out there about reduced orders at your biggest customer and really based on bottlenecks within the supply chain. I haven't really heard that addressed or referenced too much during the call, and I wanted to see if we could get a perspective around that.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's no way that we could talk about supply chain bottlenecks or anything to do with any individual customer's business.
componenttext: There's no way that we could talk about supply chain bottlenecks or anything to do with any individual customer's business.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, looks like we'll move to the second question. All right. So when you think about your new business, is there a way, Tim or Mark, if you could provide an overview of how you're looking at the ramps on the horizon this year, perhaps where you fe
componenttext: Okay. Well, looks like we'll move to the second question. All right. So when you think about your new business, is there a way, Tim or Mark, if you could provide an overview of how you're looking at the ramps on the horizon this year, perhaps where you feel a little bit more confident in realizing the intended scale and timing of programs maybe rolled out at a segment level versus where there may be modifications on the state of the macroenvironment, are there some areas being affected a little bit more so than others?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think in terms of weakness for the last couple of quarters, and I think in terms of the present trends, any business area that relies on business spending, capital spending and government spending has been really big weak. And really over the last 4, 5
componenttext: I think in terms of weakness for the last couple of quarters, and I think in terms of the present trends, any business area that relies on business spending, capital spending and government spending has been really big weak. And really over the last 4, 5 months of the year, we can do even further. So I think in terms of business confidence we need to see that turnaround a little bit, so that those capital spending areas can improve. That said, we feel like we have line of sight to adequate enterprise infrastructure growth for the year even in the poor spending environment. So we actually feel good about that. In the High Velocity area, there has been some weaknesses as Forbes outlined in set-top boxes and printers. There's really not much to make us believe that there'll be any type of robust recovery in those business areas any time soon. Our mobility business on the other hand is -- looks like that could trend upwards over the course of the year. So I guess we're cautiously optimistic about that element. In Diversified Manufacturing Services, as I said, the industrial and health care areas are relatively stable. And we do have a pipeline of opportunity that could supply -- not spectacular growth but growth. And if we see the Clean Tech and instrumentation -- a lot improve a little bit, that would really contribute to a better margins next year in the DMS area. In Aftermarket Services, they are in the midst of ramping some very large, very complex customers. If those are -- if those customers are successfully, ramped over the course of the next quarter or 2, I think that could contribute to a much better earnings and margin performance in the second half of the year. And then in the Materials Technology Group, we think that will be another good year of growth.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to dig a little bit into the DMS segment. The guidance was 4 up 7% year-over-year and I think your long-term guidance is 4 15%. I think just to get any to see some improvement in the back half? Just trying to understand what the puts and tak
componenttext: I just wanted to dig a little bit into the DMS segment. The guidance was 4 up 7% year-over-year and I think your long-term guidance is 4 15%. I think just to get any to see some improvement in the back half? Just trying to understand what the puts and takes are in that 7% being below your expectations. And should we assume you'll see some improvement in the back half in that segment?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd say that you're applying a long-term target to a single quarter in a seasonally down quarter at that. It was up 20% in the first quarter. So I think when we look back at this time this year that next year, we'll easily see a 15% growth rate for the ye
componenttext: I'd say that you're applying a long-term target to a single quarter in a seasonally down quarter at that. It was up 20% in the first quarter. So I think when we look back at this time this year that next year, we'll easily see a 15% growth rate for the year. So not filled with much, much concern there. This is -- with the growth in Specialized Services in that business, Sherri, that's going to be a little bit more seasonal than maybe it has been historically as that part of the business increases as a percentage of the total DMS area. So still feel very good about the 15% year-over-year growth.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just a technical question for Forbes, I think the share count guidance for the second quarter was flat Q-over-Q but you guys did a lot of buybacks in the first quarter. Was that first quarter buyback weighted to the beginning of the
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just a technical question for Forbes, I think the share count guidance for the second quarter was flat Q-over-Q but you guys did a lot of buybacks in the first quarter. Was that first quarter buyback weighted to the beginning of the quarter or should we expect the share count to be maybe a little bit lower than the 208?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was predominantly weighted earlier on in the quarter, Sherri. We do have the issuance of some equity, a typical period of equity issuance is late in October this year. So we will have the full effect of that issuance offsetting some of that buybac
componenttext: Yes, it was predominantly weighted earlier on in the quarter, Sherri. We do have the issuance of some equity, a typical period of equity issuance is late in October this year. So we will have the full effect of that issuance offsetting some of that buyback in the second fiscal quarter.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to our first quarter of 2013 earnings call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; Chief Operating Officer, Mark Mondello; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.This call is being recorded and will be posted for
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to our first quarter of 2013 earnings call. Joining me today are President and CEO, Timothy Main; Chief Operating Officer, Mark Mondello; and Chief Financial Officer, Forbes Alexander.
This call is being recorded and will be posted for audio playback on the Jabil website, jabil.com, in the Investors section. Our first quarter press release and corresponding webcast with slides are also available on the website. In these slides, you will find the financial information that we cover during this conference call. We ask that you follow our presentation with the slides on the website, beginning with Slide 2, our forward-looking statement.
During this conference call, we will be making forward-looking statements including those regarding anticipated outlook for our business, our currently expected second quarter of fiscal 2013 net revenue and earnings results, our long-term outlook for our company and improvements in our operational efficiencies and financial performance. These statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially. An extensive list of these risks and uncertainties are identified in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2012, on subsequent reports on Form 10-Q and Form 8-K and our other securities filings. Jabil disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Today's call will begin with our first fiscal quarter results, highlights and comments from Forbes Alexander, as well as guidance for our second fiscal quarter of 2013. Tim Main will follow with macroeconomic and Jabil-specific comments about our performance. We will then open up the call to questions from call attendees.
I will now turn the call over to Forbes.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Beth. Hello, everyone. I'll ask you to please refer to Slide 3.Net revenue for the first quarter was $4.6 billion, an increase of 7.2% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $170.3 million or 3.7% of revenue. This compares to $1
componenttext:
Thank you, Beth. Hello, everyone. I'll ask you to please refer to Slide 3.
Net revenue for the first quarter was $4.6 billion, an increase of 7.2% on a year-over-year basis. GAAP operating income was $170.3 million or 3.7% of revenue. This compares to $170.8 million GAAP operating income on revenues of $4.3 billion or 3.9% for the same period in the prior year.
Diluted earnings per share were $0.51. Core operating income, excluding amortization of intangibles and stock-based compensation decreased 1% to $192.5 million. It represents 4.2% of revenue. This compares to $194.6 million or 4.5% for the same period in the prior year. Core diluted earnings per share were $0.61.
If you now please turn to Slide 4 where I'll discuss our segments. In the first quarter, our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment grew 20% on a year-over-year basis, driven by continued strength in Specialized Services though offset by weakness in instrumentation, Clean Tech products related to the Smart Grid rollout encompassing meters, solar and wind-related products. Revenue for this segment was approximately $2.2 billion, representing 47% of total company revenue. Core operating income expanded in the quarter to 5.8% of revenue.
The Enterprise & Infrastructure segment increased 17% on a year-over-year basis as we'd expected. Revenue was approximately $1.4 billion, representing 30% total company revenue in the first quarter. Core operating income for the segment is consistent with the previous quarter of 2.4% of revenue.
High Velocity segment decreased 20% on a year-over-year basis, driven primarily by declines in handset volumes. Revenue was $1 billion, representing approximately 23% of total company revenue. Revenue performed better than our guidance as we saw strength in the quarter on handset volumes, offset by weakness in printing and set-top box revenues. As a result, core operating income for this segment was 3.2% of revenue.
I'll now ask you to refer to Slide 5. We ended the quarter with cash balances of approximately $1.03 billion. During the quarter, cash flows from operations were, as expected, approximately $152 million. Capital expenditures were $165 million with majority of these investments being focused towards our Diversified Manufacturing Services segment. In addition, during the course of the quarter, we purchased approximately 7.3 million shares, totaling $129 million, an average price of $17.58, exhausting our approved stock repurchase program. Our sales cycle increased by approximately 2 days, primarily as a result of growth in inventory levels, positioned to support revenue levels in the first month of our second fiscal quarter.
Our core EBITDA in the quarter was approximately $284 million, representing 6.1% of revenue, and our GAAP return on invested capital for the quarter was 21%. We're pleased with the operating performance in our first fiscal quarter. Core operating performance is well within our expected range while revenue is above. We're off to a great start in terms of our cash generation with continued expectations of generating $1 billion from operational cash flows in the current fiscal year.
I'm also very pleased to note that earlier in December, Standard & Poor's upgraded our corporate credit and senior unsecured issue ratings to BBB- from BB+. Our capital expenditure estimates for the fiscal year remain in the previously guided range. And we now expect expenditures to be -- excuse me, to be towards the higher end of that range for $500 million. And we continue to make investments to support ongoing growth in our Diversified Manufacturing Services footprint and capabilities.
If you now please turn to Slide 7 and 8 where I'll discuss our second quarter guidance. We expect revenue in the second quarter on a year-over-year basis to increase approximately 4% to be within the range of $4.3 billion to $4.5 billion. Core operating income is estimated to be in the range of $165 million to $185 million, and core operating margin in the range of 3.8% to 4.1%.
Our GAAP earnings per share are estimated to be in the range of $0.40 to $0.48 per diluted share, and core earnings per share estimated to be in the range of $0.50 to $0.58 per diluted share. This has been based upon a diluted share count of 208 million shares. Based on the current estimates of production, tax rate from core operating income is expected to remain at 22% for the quarter and the full fiscal year. Capital expenditures in the quarter are estimated to be $200 million.
Turning to our segments. The year-on-year performance, the Diversified Manufacturing Services segment is expected to increase 7%, the Enterprise & Infrastructure segment is expected to increase 15% and finally, our High Velocity segment is expected to decline 13% on a year-over-year basis.
I'd now like to hand the call over to Tim Main.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Forbes. This was an interesting quarter. The primary takeaway for me is the robust revenue growth, which I think is remarkable in the current environment. I would also highlight growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services, which rose to 47% of
componenttext:
Thank you, Forbes. This was an interesting quarter. The primary takeaway for me is the robust revenue growth, which I think is remarkable in the current environment. I would also highlight growth in Diversified Manufacturing Services, which rose to 47% of our overall business. On each of these dimensions, the quarter was record-setting for the company. Growth in Enterprise & Infrastructure was a bit better than planned, which was welcomed in an otherwise lackluster demand environment.
Year-over-year, margins were up 40 basis points. I'd like to see more progress, but we believe we are on path to be within our targeted range by year end. We are making investments in complex order fulfillment capabilities diluting near-term progress. The new leadership of this business area is taking a page from the High Velocity Playbook, focusing on customer service and lean manufacturing principles to improve results further. In the High Velocity sector, business conditions weakened a bit. A notable exception of this being mobility products, which enjoyed a stronger-than-expected quarter. The sector overall, we are pleased with the results and prospects for the year.
Our DMS sector is now pacing in excess of $8 billion per year. We've enjoyed multiple years of strong growth and now have significant scale to build upon. Quarter-on-quarter, margins improved 50 basis points and are within our targeted long-term range. Additional growth and improvements in our Healthcare & Instrumentation, and our Industrial & Clean Tech businesses have served to drive margins higher in the range.
Specialized Services and, in particular, our Materials Technology Group, continued to leverage growth to remarkable levels. Specialized Services is now 31% of our overall business, representing a unique value stream for Jabil. AMS is investing in expanding capabilities to advance logistics and IT-intensive services in emerging markets while also expanding to serve new verticals. The MTG group has become a leader in both innovation and scale, and we will continue to invest in MTG's growth. Specialized Services is a higher value add on electronics set of capabilities, providing us with solid diversification and new paths for future growth. Our focused strategy of driving growth and returns in a differentiated manner continues. Please turn to Slide 10.
Now I'll take a moment to discuss this slide. Here, we compare Jabil's DMS sector size and growth rate with that of our North American competition. We have taken publicly available information and then reconciled the data to provide as close to an apples-to-apples comparison as possible, adjusted to a calendar year basis. The X axis of this chart reflects the dollars of revenue added to the respective DMS sectors in the last 3 calendar years, the years being 2010 through 2012. The Y axis reflects compound annual growth rate over that same time frame, while the bubbles are representative of the estimated calendar 2012 revenue for each provider. Jabil is represented by the green bubble.
You can see that Jabil's added approximately $3 billion of revenue in the Diversified Manufacturing segment during the period, with compound annual growth rate approximating 30%. Jabil's DMS revenues are expected to be about $7.8 billion in calendar 2012, representing an excess of 40% of the total DMS revenue expected by North American providers for the year.
Jabil is in a unique position, enjoying the benefit of diversification and scale that comes with successfully competing in E&I, High Velocity and DMS sectors. With efficient operations in E&I and High Velocity, combined with a large and growing presence in Diversified Manufacturing Services, we are in an advantaged position to drive margin and cash flow generation.
Please turn to Slide 11. Here, we compare absolute EBITDA dollars in margins among the largest North American EMS providers with the most recent trailing 12-month period. The bubble size and X axis exhibit absolute EBITDA dollars while the Y axis exhibit EBITDA margins. Two companies dominate the market today and are responsible for over 70% of the dollars generated in the industry. However, Jabil's intense focus and operational efficiency and growth in DMS, places it in a unique position of combining scale and cash flow. Perhaps this is one of the reasons Jabil's recently upgraded to investment grade by S&P. We plan to continue investing in our capabilities, Customer Services and people. We are in a competitive business and understand we must continuously improve our value proposition for customers. With this in mind and in spite of the uncertain environment, we remain optimistic about our prospects for the future.

componenttext: Just a couple questions, 2 questions for me. I guess, one just on the Feb quarter guide, you guys are talking about the DMS segment being down 8%, 9% sequentially. Surely, you have a sense, do you think that can be uniform across the 3 subsectors, or do you think the health and industrial segment may start to hit a bottom from a revenue basis, or do you think it's going to get a bit more softer? And the Specialized Services [indiscernible] if you could just maybe address that, that will be helpful.

componenttext:
I think within the Specialized Services area, there's certainly a lot of smartphone content, mobility content, which does have a seasonal element. I think we should see that Healthcare & Instrumentation and the Industrial & Clean Tech stabilize in Q2, Q3 and then start to grow again as we get to the second half of the year.
But it's primarily a seasonal pattern, Amit.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then if you could maybe just touch on the inventory numbers, I think it was up about 9% sequentially in November. Could you just talk about what drove that? Is that for some ramps that you have building up for the Feb quarter? And if you coul
componenttext: Perfect. And then if you could maybe just touch on the inventory numbers, I think it was up about 9% sequentially in November. Could you just talk about what drove that? Is that for some ramps that you have building up for the Feb quarter? And if you could talk of maybe how much of that was finished goods versus raw material will be helpful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Amit, this is Forbes. In terms of our overall spread of inventory, finished goods is pretty consistent with the patterns we see, and I believe that's -- we're in about 13% to 14% of the inventory levels, and that's been pretty consistent now for the
componenttext: Yes, Amit, this is Forbes. In terms of our overall spread of inventory, finished goods is pretty consistent with the patterns we see, and I believe that's -- we're in about 13% to 14% of the inventory levels, and that's been pretty consistent now for the last 2 or 3 years. So nothing extraordinary there. Finished goods did rise I think on average about $30 million to $40 million. So the overall growth in inventory is prepositioning of inventory for this upcoming quarter. There's still a lot of mobility product to be built and shipped in the early part of this quarter that sell-through into carriers and such like. So that's the main reason, and then we should see that start to normalize in our second fiscal quarter.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: The business is growing at about 9%, 10% year-over-year. So the pipeline of opportunity is good there. They have extended their business into some very advanced logistics and forward logistics capabilities, taking on new business areas in places like the
componenttext: The business is growing at about 9%, 10% year-over-year. So the pipeline of opportunity is good there. They have extended their business into some very advanced logistics and forward logistics capabilities, taking on new business areas in places like the African continent and other areas that are very challenging, very IT-intensive and are really stretching their capabilities. We think long term, they will pay -- those efforts will pay really extraordinary dividends. We're active as always in looking for acquisitions and other opportunities to build capabilities there. But right now, they're played as very full with the customers and pipeline of opportunity that they have on an organic basis.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: So looks like you're guiding revenue down about 5% sequentially, EPS down about 12% if I use the midpoint of the guidance. So can you just talk about the operating margin decline that you're looking for in the February quarter in 20 basis points or so? Ho
componenttext: So looks like you're guiding revenue down about 5% sequentially, EPS down about 12% if I use the midpoint of the guidance. So can you just talk about the operating margin decline that you're looking for in the February quarter in 20 basis points or so? How much of that is being driven by the mix shift away from DMS, and how much would you attribute to margin declines within some of your segments? And if you can maybe just give some directional color on margins by segment, that would be helpful.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's pretty tough to isolate how much of it is just deleveraging on the revenue being down, and how much of it is associated by segment because it's kind of tough to pick apart. It's really very consistent if you look back over our history, it's actually
componenttext: It's pretty tough to isolate how much of it is just deleveraging on the revenue being down, and how much of it is associated by segment because it's kind of tough to pick apart. It's really very consistent if you look back over our history, it's actually a very low level of seasonality in terms of being 5% down for the last 3, 4 years have been low single to 5% kind of seasonality. So a lot less than it's historically been. And the level of income that's coming out of the model for Q2 is very consistent with deleveraging, probably a little bit less than what we've seen historically. Now historically, we see something on the order of $0.15 to $0.20 on the dollar. And in this case, it's less than that. So I don't think it should be surprising from a deleveraging standpoint. Directionally, in terms of margins for the business, I said on the last conference call and I'd just reiterate that here a little bit, we see that Enterprise & Infrastructure and High Velocity margins -- call lessening in the 3% range, notwithstanding the fact that they have different long-term targets at least in the next 3 to 5 quarters. I think we'd expect the average of the 2 to be in the 3% range, maybe a little bit better as we exit that period. But we're kind of an average of 3%. And I think that in terms of the Diversified Manufacturing Services, if you look forward a few quarters, we should be able to average 6% or a little bit better. So that would model to something in the mid-4s for the company overall, which we think is a reasonable way to look at it beyond Q2. So looking at Q3, Q4, maybe Q1 of 2014.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just a quick follow-up, Tim, on the -- I didn't hear you allude to the EPS growth for fiscal '13. I think last quarter we talked about 5% to 10% growth. So I don't know if that's still something that you're expecting or if that's off the table. I th
componenttext: Okay. Just a quick follow-up, Tim, on the -- I didn't hear you allude to the EPS growth for fiscal '13. I think last quarter we talked about 5% to 10% growth. So I don't know if that's still something that you're expecting or if that's off the table. I think you need to generate about 55% of the year in the second half. So just thought I would check on that.

componenttext: Yes, I don't think we're not pulling away from the 5% to 10% although I'd say based on the fact that the first half of the year is about what we thought it'd be that we probably trend more towards the low end of that 5% to 10% range.

componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Forbes, maybe just an appreciation of why the turnaround or improvement in E&I margins appears to be taking longer, revenue seem to be holding up relatively well. So I was hoping you can maybe just touch on that. And then for High Velocity, as we move into the February quarter, one of your mobile customers will be ramping. Should we expect operating margin to stay above the 3% range, or do you think we could probably see the operating margins in the high 2s?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. How are you doing? In regards to the E&I margins, I actually think we're on track. We -- we put the team in place from High Velocity and exploiting some of our High Velocity capabilities. So they're in the process of consolidating resources,
componenttext: This is Mark. How are you doing? In regards to the E&I margins, I actually think we're on track. We -- we put the team in place from High Velocity and exploiting some of our High Velocity capabilities. So they're in the process of consolidating resources, managing cost-containment, driving lowest landed car solutions, optimizing working capital and improving operational efficiencies, but at the same time taking great care of the customers and providing good customer service. As we had talked about recently on the road we feel optimistic about getting to the 3% with little and no wind in our back as far as revenue recovery, to the extent we get some type of macroeconomic recovery that will help that much more.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just on HVS margins as we look at the February quarter?
componenttext: And just on HVS margins as we look at the February quarter?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, that's -- directionally, the -- as we look into the February quarter, we've experienced some weakness in printing and set-top box as we've gone through the first quarter and we're seeing some similar patterns as we move into Q2 with some seas
componenttext: Yes, I mean, that's -- directionally, the -- as we look into the February quarter, we've experienced some weakness in printing and set-top box as we've gone through the first quarter and we're seeing some similar patterns as we move into Q2 with some seasonal adjustment there. Some strength in handset, can't discuss particular customers plans there, but obviously we have a customer within High Velocity that clearly looking to launch product sometime during our second fiscal quarter. We'll see how that plays out. But we have seen some drift down in the margin just as that handset content increases within relative scale in our High Velocity. So depending where those volumes goes, so I would say to be consistent to maybe down a little bit depending on the levels of handset volumes we see sell-through in Q2.

componenttext: Okay. And then on the E&I segment, where you continue to see some good growth there relative to the end markets obviously, being weak, how much of that is on the new program ramps versus what you're seeing from your customers in terms of end demand and if you could be specific about the new program ramps or pipeline within that business, breaking down into the various segments of that industry.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just answer that in general terms. I think that most of what we're seeing on E&I in the early half of fiscal year '13 and carrying to the back half of the year winds that we realized mid- to end of fiscal year '12, the market conditions have
componenttext: Yes, I would just answer that in general terms. I think that most of what we're seeing on E&I in the early half of fiscal year '13 and carrying to the back half of the year winds that we realized mid- to end of fiscal year '12, the market conditions have been quite tough in that entire sector. The one good thing is we continue to serve some of the best brands, whether it be in storage, networking or telecom. What we are seeing is, is if there's any uptick, the carriers and the NSPs are starting to spend some level of CapEx for network and infrastructure expansion, especially around the 4G and the LTE area. But as far as specific program wins or whatnot, I'd rather keep it at a general level.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on that, Mark, relative to the pricing environment, we obviously saw the Juniper and Plexus news talk from other AMS guys about a little bit more pricing pressure. Obviously, a tough market to begin with. Are you starting
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on that, Mark, relative to the pricing environment, we obviously saw the Juniper and Plexus news talk from other AMS guys about a little bit more pricing pressure. Obviously, a tough market to begin with. Are you starting to see some more pricing pressure on these new deals?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't characterize it as new pricing pressure. We've been in that market a long time, and we're always under pretty intense pricing pressures. So as I alluded to earlier, we got -- I think Tim in his prepared statements called it our High Velocity Pl
componenttext: I wouldn't characterize it as new pricing pressure. We've been in that market a long time, and we're always under pretty intense pricing pressures. So as I alluded to earlier, we got -- I think Tim in his prepared statements called it our High Velocity PlayBook. What he is alluding to there is that we're taking some of our consumer-type High Velocity capabilities, again around cost containment and optimizing working capital and consolidating resources, et cetera, et cetera, to be sure that we cannot only offer competitive pricing but get reasonable returns and get us to the 3% margin range by the end of the year.

componenttextpreview: Just in general, Tim, just any kind of new program commentary just going forward beyond what we've already talked about.
componenttext: Just in general, Tim, just any kind of new program commentary just going forward beyond what we've already talked about.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little too diverse and dispersed to really characterize any major new programs that we've won. Some of the areas of our business we're actually precluded from talking about new wins, but we feel good about it being a growth year. I think most peopl
componenttext: Yes, a little too diverse and dispersed to really characterize any major new programs that we've won. Some of the areas of our business we're actually precluded from talking about new wins, but we feel good about it being a growth year. I think most people would be looking for a top line growth this year. We're off to a really a fabulous start. So in terms of FY '13 over FY '12, it should be a good year. Mark alluded to in Enterprise & Infrastructure at least, wins that were secured in FY '12 contributing to FY '13 revenues. So in Specialized Services, we do have an aftermarket services business there that's growing. That's a component of Specialized Services. Our MTG group does have a high level of concentration, although we do business with -- we do business with virtually every major mobility company in the world today. So that revenue is a little bit more diverse than what maybe people think. It's expanding into areas, other areas of Consumer Electronics, optics and health care, which we hope to accelerate in the near future. We -- and within customers, it's always objective of the company to diversify within each major customer. So there's a quite a bit of program and product diversity within our MTG group. I think people tend to think about that as very one-dimensional in terms of product, and we participate in a broad range of products over 25, 30 different programs and literally hundreds of different part numbers. So that stream of value is quite a bit more diverse in terms of product categories and what folks have typically associated with it. So...

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, I appreciate that. That's very helpful. And then just a quick follow-up, just to be clear, you guys have had some Jabil-specific issues that have affected the margins over the last few quarters, but if I understood the commentary correctly, there's so
componenttext: No, I appreciate that. That's very helpful. And then just a quick follow-up, just to be clear, you guys have had some Jabil-specific issues that have affected the margins over the last few quarters, but if I understood the commentary correctly, there's some investments going on in E&I but generally speaking, as we look at the margins for the rest of the year, we're basically looking at margins being driven by revenues quarter-to-quarter changes in revenues, or are there other things we should factor in?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, for Q2, I think you just have to take it for what it is. It's revenue deleveraging and still looking at a growth year for Jabil. So that would imply that the second half of the year will be very good from a revenue and margin standpoint. At least th
componenttext: Well, for Q2, I think you just have to take it for what it is. It's revenue deleveraging and still looking at a growth year for Jabil. So that would imply that the second half of the year will be very good from a revenue and margin standpoint. At least that's the way we see it today. And I think we would see some -- particularly if we get some tailwind in the Healthcare & Instrumentation and Industrial & Clean Tech areas that's stabilized and start to improve a little bit, that the DMS margins might start with a 6 in the second half of the year, and between the E&I and High Velocity segments, if we average 3, that would imply operating margins for the company overall in the mid-4s. By the end of the year, based on growth rates, we should see Diversified Manufacturing Services become 50% of our business.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your DMS segment margins improved nicely relative to last quarter. Tim, can you give us some sense of what percent of capacity has been ramped up so far or maybe which inning you're in with the ramps in Specialized Services, such that is it like realistic
componenttext: Your DMS segment margins improved nicely relative to last quarter. Tim, can you give us some sense of what percent of capacity has been ramped up so far or maybe which inning you're in with the ramps in Specialized Services, such that is it like realistic to think that exiting next quarter, the drag from the ongoing ramps will be entirely behind you?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're in a kind of a continuous state of capacity expansion. Forbes mentioned CapEx trending towards the high end of the $500 million range, which means it will be adding capacity throughout the year. So we're at very high levels of utilization. We will b
componenttext:
We're in a kind of a continuous state of capacity expansion. Forbes mentioned CapEx trending towards the high end of the $500 million range, which means it will be adding capacity throughout the year. So we're at very high levels of utilization. We will be building additional capacity, all of which is in Specialized Services but fundamentally, the vast majority of it in the Diversified Manufacturing Services. So in terms of the drag, I think a lot of the interruptions that we highlighted in our Q4 call started to decline over the course of Q1, and we feel much better about the position that we're in today. I think margins would've been better in DMS if we had not seen a fairly significant decline in Clean Tech and Instrumentation business, which is very understandable, given the dynamics and particularly when you start thinking about renewable energy and Smart Grid metering, which tend to be government- and subsidy-related.
So I think as that stabilizes and we start to improve margins in the health care and industrial areas that the overall DMS margin picture can improve.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. And just a follow-up, I mean, you mentioned I think in your answer to the last question that you could get to 6% DMS margins in the back half. But could you get there even if your levels of revenue at -- in sort of the Healthcare & Instrument
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. And just a follow-up, I mean, you mentioned I think in your answer to the last question that you could get to 6% DMS margins in the back half. But could you get there even if your levels of revenue at -- in sort of the Healthcare & Instrumentation and Industrial & Clean Tech remain at levels where they are today?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that's possible. I mean, we'll have to see how things go. We have growth in health care and industrial. Actually, if you isolate the health care only business, it's actually very stable, and we're positioned for some growth. And the same is true o
componenttext: I think that's possible. I mean, we'll have to see how things go. We have growth in health care and industrial. Actually, if you isolate the health care only business, it's actually very stable, and we're positioned for some growth. And the same is true of the Industrial business. If you isolate Clean Tech from the industrial area, the industrial business has been very stable and poised for growth for the balance of the year. So we just kind of need the Instrumentation and Clean Tech areas to be stable. We don't need to grow, they just need to stop eroding to the extent that they did in the last quarter, and then we'll see the Industrial and Health Care business grow and that will be accretive to the overall business.

And then the second question is with the buyback complete and good prices, are you looking to do another buyback here during the remainder of the year?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure how many square feet we've added. It's about to accommodate $500 million worth of stuff. I'm not being obtuse on purpose. I really -- I just don't know offhand, and I'm not sure that's a metric that will be valuable anyways. But we're adding
componenttext: I'm not sure how many square feet we've added. It's about to accommodate $500 million worth of stuff. I'm not being obtuse on purpose. I really -- I just don't know offhand, and I'm not sure that's a metric that will be valuable anyways. But we're adding a lot of space. Forbes, do you want to address that?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we said -- as you say, we've completed the stock repurchase. Certainly, at this juncture, no immediate plans to increase that or look for additional repurchase authorization. But we're well positioned in terms of our cash generation this year. I stil
componenttext: Yes, we said -- as you say, we've completed the stock repurchase. Certainly, at this juncture, no immediate plans to increase that or look for additional repurchase authorization. But we're well positioned in terms of our cash generation this year. I still expect about $1 billion of cash flow. As we said earlier, we now expect our CapEx to be at the $500 million level. But we wanted to continue to manage the balance sheet conservatively as we move forward here and make sure we do have liquidity available to continue to invest where we feel it's appropriate to do that. Enhancing our capabilities via acquisition or continued on this really good organic growth path we're on.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012

componenttext: I guess with the $500 million, does that give you breathing room in terms of utilization within DMS? Are you still going to be kind of running up against it?

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I think that will -- once we deploy -- I mean, that would certainly give us some breathing room. Obviously, we're laying down additional square footage. We thought a couple of quarters go about expansion in Chengdu with up to 2 million square feet. We
componenttext: So I think that will -- once we deploy -- I mean, that would certainly give us some breathing room. Obviously, we're laying down additional square footage. We thought a couple of quarters go about expansion in Chengdu with up to 2 million square feet. We don't at this juncture plan on building the full 2 million. But certainly, we'd expect perhaps half of that as we exit the end of '13, we'll see how that plays. But certainly, there will be some capacity, and we'll review that as we move through the fiscal year as to demand patterns we're seeing there.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: When we look at your guidance and -- well, I'm talking the February quarter year-over-year and now I'm looking at year-over-year that kind of remove seasonality. Can you help us understand why EPS is not growing, yet sales is growing and DMS is a much big
componenttext: When we look at your guidance and -- well, I'm talking the February quarter year-over-year and now I'm looking at year-over-year that kind of remove seasonality. Can you help us understand why EPS is not growing, yet sales is growing and DMS is a much bigger part of your company? Is it still the yield issues within DMS? And if so, when you talk about 5% to 10% EPS growth this year, if my math is correct, that would be materially second half ramp, is that correct? And how should we think about how you can get from not year-over-year EPS growth right now, but yet such a big increase in the second half of the year. And my follow-up question, which is probably for Forbes, use of cash, stock buyback, you finished it. You did quite a bit looking ahead CapEx, up a little bit. But is your planned use for cash now more centered around M&A, engineering, talent, CapEx, dividend? Help us better understand your, viewpoint for cash because you're looking to be in a quite healthy situation.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Yes, I think year-over-year when we look at the DMS margins, they're down about 90 basis points. That's -- we're not pleased with that. We'd like to see that be in a higher register in the 6 range for sure at least. A lot of that is investmen
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. Yes, I think year-over-year when we look at the DMS margins, they're down about 90 basis points. That's -- we're not pleased with that. We'd like to see that be in a higher register in the 6 range for sure at least. A lot of that is investments in AMS and the aforementioned headwinds that we're seeing in the Clean Tech and instrumentation area, our Specialized Services area's actually doing relatively well year-over-year. So -- and again, I think we'll see marginal improvement in that area in the second half of the year. So -- now and I think we're really pleased with the 50 basis point improvement in that area quarter-on-quarter. Now our targeted range is 5.5 to 7, and we're at 5.8 and a little bit better improvement, and we'll see 6s again.

headline: Jabil Circuit Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Dec 19, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of the cash flow, Jim, I think you hit the nail on the head there. We're in a really strong position from a cash generation perspective. And as I said to previous comments, our main focus with that cash generation is to ensure liquidity to focus
componenttext:
In terms of the cash flow, Jim, I think you hit the nail on the head there. We're in a really strong position from a cash generation perspective. And as I said to previous comments, our main focus with that cash generation is to ensure liquidity to focus on what has been -- in this macroeconomic backdrop, impressive growth organically and also from an engineering talent perspective, from an acquisition perspective, should we feel we need to further expand our capabilities or enhance the revenue stream.
That's our key focus. We are committed to our dividend as it sits today, and we'll see how the balance of the year goes in terms of that cash generation. But we feel really good about the position we're in.
